More cylinders of gas were brought into the bottle room while the vessel was in the shipyard and the defendants missed yet another opportunity to put the shipyard on notice that there was flammable gas in the bottle room. Having not alerted the plaintiffs in the manner required, Mr M Sivasamy nonetheless tried to shift some blame to the plaintiffs when he stated in his affidavit that at a meeting of the Vessel Safety Co-ordinating Committee (hereinafter referred to as `VSCC`) on 18 February 1996, he emphasised to Mr Chiang Cher Moh, the project leader in charge of the repair project, `that the flammable nature of the gas in the room made it necessary for the mechanical ventilator to be functional at the earliest`. He also said that he reminded Mr Chiang Cher Moh at a meeting on 19 February 1996 to fix the mechanical ventilator. His evidence is clearly flawed. Apart from the fact that Mr Chiang Cher Moh denied that the said conversations took place, there was no VSCC meeting on 18 February 1996. Furthermore, Mr Chiang Cher Moh was already on leave on 18 February 1996 and he did not return to the shipyard until 23 February 1996. As such, Mr M Sivasamy could not have reminded Mr Chiang Cher Moh to have the mechanical ventilator repaired on 19 February 1996.
 20.If all the facts are closely examined, it is clear that if there was negligence on the part of anyone, it was negligence on the part of the defendants themselves. If Mr M Sivasamy was, as he claimed, very worried about the problem of accumulation of acetylene gas in the bottle room, he certainly failed to take steps to organise the equipment in the bottle room properly or to have the room properly ventilated. Apart from the fact that there were instances of a mixture of left and right-handed threaded fittings for the oxy-acetylene equipment, there was an acetylene cylinder which was painted in the colour usually associated with oxygen cylinders. As for the ventilation of the bottle room, Mr M Sivasamy, who claimed that he kept the bottle room door open, did not know that the bottle room had a port hole which could also have been opened. It is evident that if the bottle room door and the port hole had been left open, then cross ventilation and the natural air vent in the bottle room would have prevented an accumulation of acetylene or ensured that it would not have accumulated to the extent alleged by the defendants.
 21.Mr M Sivasamy also admitted that he failed to inform Mr Ravi, the gas engineer, to whom he handed over his duties when he went on leave on 22 February 1996, about the danger posed by a possible accumulation of acetylene gas in the bottle room because the mechanical ventilator had not been repaired. Mr M Sivasamy`s answers during cross-examination certainly did not help the defendants` case. When questioned, he said: 
Q: When you left the ship on 22 February, did you ask the gas engineer to continue to monitor the bottle room for accumulation of gas? 
A: Nothing specific about the bottle room except that the shipyard has to repair the mechanical ventilator. 
Q: You failed to appoint a safety co-ordinator. You failed to tell anyone about the bottle room when you went on leave. You failed to ensure proper ventilation. If there was an accumulation of gases, you and the persons who took over from you after you went on leave could have prevented it. You accept that. 
A: Yes.
 22.It must also be noted that if there had been a leakage of acetylene, the defendants were negligent in failing to notice it. Mr M Sivasamy conceded that if there was an acetylene leak, any person who went into the bottle room to release the valves so that the cutting torch could be used would have detected it. Another witness, Mr Jude Illango, the third engineer of The Wilson Ruby, who supervised the cutting work by Mr Shetty, the fitter on the day of the fire, also accepted that he should have checked the bottle room for leakage of acetylene on the day of the fire. When cross-examined, his answers were as follows: 
Q: Having decided to do an illegal act, what steps did you take to ensure that everything was safe; go to the bottle room to check? 
A: There was a fire extinguisher nearby and I kept a bucket of water. 
Q: Did you go to the bottle room to check if there were leaks? 
A: Fitters were cutting regularly. 
Q: Should you have checked the bottle room? 
A: I should have done that. 
Q: You should have ensured proper ventilation in the room. Did you know that the mechanical ventilator was not working? 
A: No.
 In the circumstances, even if there had been an accumulation of acetylene gas in the bottle room as a result of leakage, the plaintiffs are not responsible for the said accumulation.
 23.The third reason why the defendants` case with respect to the cause of the fire is flawed is that even if there had been an accumulation of gas in the bottle room, it has not been established that the cause of the fire which damaged the vessel was the ignition of the accumulated gas. The defendants` expert witness, Dr Abraham Koshy, who considered and ruled out the possibility of a flashback causing the explosion in the bottle room, said that the key evidence that a fire occurred prior to any explosion in the bottle room was obtained from the results of metallurgical tests conducted on the damaged cylinders from the bottle room. He asserted that these tests showed that all the damaged oxygen cylinders had undergone significant changes in their microstructures. In his view, the cause for these changes was a high intensity fire from an external source. Dr Koshy also relied on hardness tests conducted on fragments of the shattered gas cylinders in the bottle room. According to him, these tests showed that the hardness values of the damaged cylinders were high in comparison to a new unaffected cylinder. The highest value observed on a fragment of cylinder A was 319 Hv on the Vickers scale whereas the average value for a new unaffected cylinder was only 245 Hv. He pointed out that as it was the presence of martensite that significantly increased the hardness of the shattered cylinder fragments, the presence of large amounts of martensite in the oxygen cylinder which first exploded, namely, cylinder A, indicated that it was subjected to heat of at least 840[deg ]C and then subjected to rapid cooling and quenching after the explosion. He thus concluded that there must have been a leakage and build-up of acetylene gas before the explosion. As acetylene is a very unstable gas, he suggested that the heat from the sun`s rays on the day of the fire could have raised the temperature of the bulkheads of the bottle room to such an extent that the acetylene gas was ignited.
 24.Dr Koshy`s evidence is not convincing. To begin with, he submitted two reports on the metallurgical phase changes in the nature of fragments of cylinder A. The first, a report by Det Norske Veritas, did not appear to support his case. When this was pointed out to him, Dr Koshy sought to rely on the other report by a Dr Manoj Gupta from the Department of Mechanical and Production Engineering at the National University of Singapore. However, this report does not lend credence to Dr Koshy`s assertions as its thrust was rebutted by the plaintiffs` other expert witness, Dr Thomas Parry, a metallurgist, who pointed out that the metallurgical evidence from the microstructures of the metal samples recovered from the scene of the incident does not support the hypothesis that a fire occurred in the bottle room before the explosion on 25 February 1996. Dr Parry, who disagreed with Dr Koshy`s assertion that the values of the hardness measured from cylinder remnants were high relative to that of a new unaffected cylinder, said that evidence of the presence of martensite provided no information as to when this phase was formed. All the same, he thought that the most likely explanation for the presence of martensite within the samples examined from, inter alia, cylinder A would be that this is an artefact of normal heat treatment received during manufacture. Dr Parry also pointed out that the principal requirement for the formation of martensite is rapid cooling after it has been heated to the required temperature and he was not sure what was the source of quenching and rapid cooling in Dr Koshy`s scenario. Dr Koshy replied that the quenching of the fragments occurred when cool air rushed into the bottle room after the explosion. It is difficult to believe that this was the case.
 25.Equally damaging to Dr Koshy`s assertions is the fact that the defendants` other expert witness, Mr Barry Dillon, a metallurgist, supported Dr Parry`s conclusions and disagreed with Dr Koshy and Dr Manoj Gupta. Mr Dillon, who must be commended for his candid and helpful views, pointed out that the microstructure of the fragments of cylinder A that was seen in the reports of Det Norske Veritas and Dr Manoj Gupta could only have resulted from heating to a high temperature, quenching and tempering. All three processes occurred in that order in a factory and he thought that it was highly unlikely that all these could have occurred by chance during a fire in the bottle room.
 26.Dr Koshy could not explain why there were burn marks in the oxygen hose. In fact, after examining the hose in court, he refused to concede that some of the holes in the hose had burn marks even though it was fairly obvious that they did. He explained that heat from the heated cylinders passed into the pipes and softened the oxygen hose. He argued that the holes in the hose were the result of pressure waves travelling down the line, possibly from the exploding cylinders. This argument cannot be countenanced because the first large hole in the hose would have released the pressure and no other holes down the line, or at least not the number found on the hose, would have been created. Equally disturbing is the fact that he could not satisfactorily explain why paint remained on the inside and outside of the neck of the shattered cylinder and why the rubber therein had not melted. If the shattered cylinder had been subjected to heating at 840[deg ]C, as alleged by Dr Koshy, there would have been enough heat at the neck of the cylinder to melt the paint and to char the rubber. Furthermore, the wooden platform, on which the cylinder stood, was quite intact although it was slightly burnt. All these show that there could not have been a fire, and certainly not one of the intensity suggested by Dr Koshy, in the bottle room before the explosion.
 27.As for the argument put forward by the plaintiffs` expert witness, Mr David Robbins, that cylinder A did not explode as a result of heating from a pre-existing fire in the bottle room because it was broken into a large number of small pieces after it exploded, Dr Koshy suggested that the fragments of the exploded cylinder A were propelled at very high velocity against the bulkhead of the gas storage room, including the steel door. In his view, the impact from this collision caused a further shattering of the fragments of cylinder A into smaller pieces. That this was the case is most unlikely for as Dr Parry aptly pointed out, Dr Koshy overlooked the most obvious effect of heating a pressurised cylinder to a temperature in excess of 840[deg ]C. At such a temperature, the steel would be significantly softened and extremely ductile and one would, therefore, not expect a cylinder in such a condition to fracture into multiple fragments. In short, the underlying strength of Mr Robbin`s point, namely, that the physical evidence cannot be satisfactorily explained on the basis that there was a deflagration explosion occurring as a result of the accumulation of a flammable gas and air mixture within the bottle store, was in no way diminished by Dr Koshy`s arguments.
 28.Reference must now be made to the written report and affidavit of the defendants` other expert witness, Mr Barry Dillon. Although Mr Dillon did not agree with Dr Koshy`s views on the significance of the results of the metallurgical tests on the damaged gas cylinders when he was cross-examined, he did say in his report that there was strong evidence that the explosion in the bottle room was that of an oxygen cylinder that had been heated by a pre-existing fire in that room. To be fair to Mr Dillon, his report must be viewed in its proper context because it had been written without the knowledge that the oxygen hose had burn holes. When the report was written, the hose and the cutting torch were still in the possession of the Ministry of Labour investigators. He accepted, when cross-examined, that had the information regarding the holes in the hose been before him, his conclusion that a fire started first in the bottle room might have been different. He also conceded that having seen the hose and having heard the two conflicting versions as to how the fire started, he thought that the plaintiffs` version, namely, that the fire started as a result of a flashback from the cutting torch was `possible` if all four mechanisms devised to prevent this from happening, namely, the temperature sensitive valve, the pressure sensitive valve, the sintered metal and the return valve failed.
 29.After reading the reports of the respective experts and taking into account their oral evidence as well as the Ministry of Labour Investigation Report on the fire and explosion at the shipyard, I have no doubt that the plaintiffs` explanation as to how the fire on The Wilson Ruby started is to be preferred. It must follow that someone tried to light the cutting torch just before the fire, which broke out at around 4.15pm. No one has admitted that he used the cutting torch at the relevant time and the defendants claimed that the cutting torch could not have been lit because their men completed the repair work which required the use of the cutting torch by 2.30pm. All the same, an inference may be drawn from the available evidence that the hot work undertaken by the defendants had not been completed by 2.30pm. If the hot work had been completed, the relevant gas valves should have been shut. This was not the case. More significant is the fact that after the fire, the oxy-acetylene gas cutting torch, a spark lighter and a metal plate were found on the floor of the engine room. The cutting torch and spark lighter should have been stored properly if the cutting work had indeed been completed. Under cross-examination, Mr M Sivasamy, the chief engineer explained: 
Q: Where do you store the ignitor? 
A: Put in drawer of the work bench. 
Q: Cutting torch? 
A: Kept on shelf. 
Q: This system was understood by the crew? 
A: A technical person like Shetty, the fitter, knows the procedure. 
Q: Is it your evidence that Shetty does cutting work and knows the procedure? 
A: Yes.
 30.Another witness, Mr Jude Illango, the third engineer of The Wilson Ruby, under whose supervision the fitter, Shetty, carried out the work involving the use of the oxy-acetylene torch on the day of the fire, also claimed in his affidavit that the cutting work had been completed by 2.30pm but his evidence left much to be desired. When cross-examined, his answers were as follows: 
Q: On that day, did Shetty tell you he has finished cutting? 
A: No. 
Q: Why did you say that the cutting work was completed? 
A: He did not tell me but I told him he can finish. 
Q: Why did he not put the torch back, intermittent valves were open, ignitor there, gas bottle valves were open? 
A: I don`t know.
 It is thus reasonable to suppose that the hot work undertaken on the day of the fire had not been completed by 2.30pm and that someone lit the oxy-acetylene torch just before the fire occurred.
 31.
 Whether the plaintiffs` fire-fighting system was adequate
A question arises as to whether the plaintiffs were responsible in any way for the spread of the fire as the defendants complained at length about the fire-fighting arrangements with respect to their vessel. The defendants claimed that the plaintiffs` fire-fighting arrangements failed to meet contractual requirements because para 2.1.7 of the `conditions of tender`, which were handed over to them by the plaintiffs, required the plaintiffs to provide a shore connection to the ship`s fire main. That this was not done is not in doubt. The plaintiffs had a system of fire-fighting which is, in their view, superior to a system which is dependent on the flow of water from the shore fire main into a vessel`s own fire main. They ran a hose from the shore fire line and left it pressurised all the time on mid-ship. This hose had a Y-breeching, which enabled other hoses to be connected in the event of a fire. Besides this hose, there was another hose which was lapped up at the ship`s side near the gangway.
 32.The so-called `conditions of tender` referred to by the defendants must be viewed in their proper context. It was prepared by Star Gas Italy on behalf of the former owners of The Wilson Ruby, who were then interested in having the vessel repaired. After the defendants purchased the vessel, they asked the plaintiffs to hand them a copy of the document, presumably to see the extent of repairs contemplated by the vessel`s former owners. This is the main role of this document. It follows that this document cannot have the effect of requiring the plaintiffs to put into place a system of fire-fighting which was not adopted by them. In any case, if the defendants believed that they had a contractual right to the benefit of another fire-fighting system, it is strange that they did not insist on their rights at an earlier date. They cannot say that they did not know that the shipyard`s own fire-fighting system was in place. When the vessel first arrived at the shipyard, the plaintiffs` personnel conducted a thorough safety briefing session with respect to the safety procedures in the yard and its fire-fighting system. The defendants` chief engineer, Mr M Sivasamy, admitted that he was aware of the shipyard`s fire-fighting system and that he knew that it did not involve connecting water from the shore`s main to the ship`s fire line. The defendants` superintendent, Mr Deepak Pandit, also testified that he knew from the time he first boarded the vessel in the shipyard that the ship`s fire main was not charged by the shipyard`s fire line.
 33.The defendants also complained that their men tried to connect their hoses to the ship`s own fire main and found that it did not work. Why they did this and why they failed to use the shipyard`s fire-fighting equipment in the proper manner cannot be understood. Mr M Sivasamy, the chief engineer of The Wilson Ruby, admitted that he had no fire plan and that he did not have any fire drills. Evidently, he had failed to communicate to his own crew the proper procedures to fight a fire and the plaintiffs cannot be held responsible for the crew`s confusion about the fire-fighting system in the shipyard.
 34.
 Conclusions
I now return to the question of bailment, which was referred to earlier on. In view of my findings, I do not have to consider the question of bailment at length. The plaintiffs are right in asserting that for the purpose of considering their duties with regard to the safety of the vessel, account must be taken of the fact that while the vessel was in the shipyard, a large number of her crew were on board for maintenance and repair work and that other contractors had been engaged by the defendants to do repair work. However, even if the defendants are right in asserting that this fact is irrelevant, the plaintiffs have satisfied me that the defendants` loss which resulted from the fire on The Wilson Ruby was not occasioned by the absence of reasonable care and skill on their part. A bailee is not an insurer for as Holt CJ explained in 
Coggs v Bernard
 
[1703] 2 Ld Raym 909
, p 918: 
He is only to do the best he can. And if he is robbed it is a good account. If he receives money and keeps it locked up with reasonable care he shall not be answerable for it though it be stolen.
 In this case, the plaintiffs took reasonable precautions and had proper safety procedures in place. Their fire-fighting equipment was in good order. There can be no doubt that the plaintiffs had done the best they could with respect to the safety of vessel while she was in their shipyard. It was the defendants` own personnel who undertook hot work without a permit or proper tools or any regard for safety rules. To allow the defendants to succeed in claiming damages from the plaintiffs would be clearly unjust.
 35.It follows that the defendants` claim for damages against the plaintiffs fails and they are not entitled to the declarations sought. As for the plaintiffs, they are entitled to judgment for the sum of $786,620.28 claimed with respect to repairs and for the sum of $350,050 claimed with respect to services rendered after the fire.
 36.As far as the claim for $350,050 is concerned, the plaintiffs are entitled to interest at the rate of 6% from the date of the writ. As for the sum of $786,620.28 claimed with respect to the repairs at the shipyard, the plaintiffs submitted that their standard conditions of contract applied and that they were entitled to interest at the rate of 1.5% per month, or 18% per annum, by virtue of cl 6 of the said standard conditions, which provided as follows: 
Unless alternative credit arrangements have been agreed, full payment for work done shall become due on completion of work. Interest at 11/2% per month will be charged on accounts overdue for payment.
 The defendants did not successfully challenge the plaintiffs` assertion that the said standard conditions of contract were handed over to them and that these conditions were terms of the contract. Admittedly, the plaintiffs were subsequently prepared to negotiate the terms of payment and to give the defendants credit for 60 days but they insisted that these negotiations, which did not result in any agreement between the parties on credit arrangements, did not affect their right to the contractual rate of interest for any delayed payment. The plaintiffs rightly pointed out that cl 6 of their standard conditions of contract made it clear that unless alternative credit arrangements had been agreed upon, interest was to be paid at the rate of 1.5% per month. The defendants contended that the offer of delayed payment terms by the plaintiffs could be construed as a waiver by the plaintiffs of their right to the contractual rate of interest. However, the question of waiver was not pleaded. Taking all circumstances into account, the plaintiffs are entitled to the contractual rate of interest of 1.5% per month in the case of their claim for $786,620.28.
 37.As for costs, the plaintiffs are entitled to taxed costs.

title: MV Balakrishnan v Public Prosecutor [1998] SGHC 231
content:
MV Balakrishnan v Public Prosecutor
[1998] SGHC 231
 
 
Case Number
 
:
 
Cr M 9/1998
 
 
 
Decision Date
 
:
 
08 July 1998
 
 
 
Tribunal/Court
 
:
 
High Court
 
 
 
Coram
 
:
 
 
Yong Pung How CJ
 
 
 
 
Counsel Name(s)
 
:
 
 Michael Hwang SC and Andrew Chan (Allen & Gledhill) for the applicant; Kow Keng Siong (Deputy Public Prosecutor) for the respondent 
 
 
 
Parties
 
:
 
 MV Balakrishnan — Public Prosecutor 
 
 
 
Courts and Jurisdiction
  – 
Court of appeal
  – 
Reference to Court of Appeal
  – 
Applicable principles
  – 
Whether stated question raised conflict of authority or serious question requiring reference to Court of Criminal Appeal
  – 
Whether application veiled appeal Road Traffic
  – 
Offences
  – 
Sentencing
  – 
Disqualification order
  – 
Whether circumstances perculiar to offender constituted 'special reasons' to dispense with mandatory disqualification
  – 
s 3(1) & (2) Motor Vehicles (Third-Party Risks and Compensation) Act (Cap 189)
 
 
Words and Phrases
  – 
'Special reasons'
  – 
s 3(2) Motor Vehicles (Third-Party Risks and Compensation) Act (Cap 189)
 
 
 
 
Judgment:
 
 
 
 1.
YONG PUNG HOW CJ
 
 Background
This was a motion arising out of my decision in MA 198/97 dismissing the appellant`s appeal against sentence and conviction. The detailed facts are set out in my grounds of decision dated 18 May 1998. Briefly, the appellant was charged with permitting his employee to use a Class 4 motor vehicle without a valid driving licence and while there was no insurance coverage against third party risks in force, offences under s 35(1) Road Traffic Act (Cap 276) (the RTA) and s 3(1) Motor Vehicles (Third Party Risks Compensation) Act (Cap 189) (the MVA) respectively.
 2.In the court below, the appellant`s defence was that he had relied on the seller`s representations that the motor vehicle was a Class 3 vehicle and therefore permitted his employee, a Class 3 driver, to use the motor vehicle. The district judge found the seller`s evidence unreliable and held that the appellant had been wilfully blind to the class of the motor vehicle. The appellant was convicted and fined $1,000 for the RTA offence and $800 for the MVA offence, and disqualified from holding all classes of licence for 12 months. On appeal, I found the appellant strictly liable for the offences charged and upheld the fines. I also found no special reasons within the meaning of s 3(2) MVA to excuse the appellant from the statutory disqualification. It was the construction of the phrase `special reasons` that formed the subject matter of this motion.
 3.Pursuant to s 60 Supreme Court of Judicature Act (Cap 322) (the SCJA) the appellant`s previous counsel sought to refer two questions to the Court of Appeal; the first concerned the district judge`s finding of `wilful blindness` while the second question turned on the construction of `special reasons` for the purposes of the MVA. By a letter dated 4 June 1998 this court was informed by the appellant`s newly instructed counsel of his intention to withdraw the first question and re-phrase the second question. In the hearing before me on 8 June 1998, the application proceeded with the second question re-phrased in the terms set out below: (a). whether the Singapore courts other than the Court of Appeal are, in construing the words `special reasons` in s 3(2) of the Motor Vehicles (Third Party Risks Compensation) Act, bound by the majority decision of the Singapore High Court of three judges in 
R v Lim Kian Soo
 
[1950] MLJ 181
 construing the words `special reasons` in the context of the predecessor section of s 3(2) of the Motor Vehicles (Third Party Risks Compensation) Act; and,
 (b). whether, if the Singapore courts other than the Court of Appeal are not bound by the majority decision of the Singapore High Court of three judges in 
R v Lim Kian Soo
 
[1950] MLJ 181
 in the manner stated above, the Singapore courts should follow the decision of the majority in 
R v Lim Kian Soo
 
[1950] MLJ 181
 .
 4.The Public Prosecutor objected to this motion. Having heard the submissions tendered by both counsel, I was satisfied that this matter should proceed no further and accordingly dismissed the application. The appellant`s argument has time and again been canvassed before this court without success. In this regard, the reasons which I now set out for my decision will prevent future waste of the court`s time.
 5.
 The motion
The question which counsel for the appellant sought to refer to the Court of Criminal Appeal asked whether circumstances particular to the offender could constitute `special reasons` within the meaning of s 3(2) MVA to dispense with the mandatory disqualification stipulated by statute. The key to the question, as submitted by counsel for the appellant, was whether recent decisions such as 
PP v Balasubramaniam
 
 
[1992] 1 SLR 822
  and 
 Joseph Roland v PP 
 
[1996] 1 SLR 179
, upholding the 1947 ruling of Lord Goddard CJ in 
Whittall v Kirby
 
[1947] KB 194
, were made in ignorance of the Singapore High Court decision in 
 R v Lim Kian Soo 
; and whether this created a conflict of authority requiring reference to the Court of Criminal Appeal. Counsel for the appellant relied on the obiter dictum of Judicial Commissioner Kan Ting Chiu (as he then was) in 
PP v Akhtar Hussain Mann
 
 
[1992] 1 SLR 266
  to argue that this question had not been unequivocally resolved. Having considered the ruling in 
 R v Lim Kian Soo 
, Kan Ting Chiu JC observed, at p 268G, that there appeared some uncertainty in Singapore whether `special reasons` extended to circumstances peculiar to an offender, adding that no such uncertainty existed in Malaya following the decision in 
PP v Teo Kok Keng
 
 
[1989] 1 MLJ 198
 . He then went on to comment that if put to choose between the construction in 
 Whittall 
 and that in 
 Lim Kian Soo 
, he would accept the former although on the facts before him he was not restricted to making such a choice.
 6.The construction in 
 Whittall 
 was an adoption of Lord Goddard CJ`s speech to magistrates and which was expressly considered in 
R v Crossan
 
[1939] NI 106
. The following extract from 
 Whittall 
 is widely quoted and reads: 
A special reason within the exception is one which is special to the facts of the particular case, that is, special to the facts which constitute the offence. It is, in other words, a mitigating or extenuating circumstance, not amounting in law to a defence to the charge, yet directly connected with the commission of the offence, and one which the court ought properly to take into consideration when imposing punishment. A circumstance peculiar to the offender as distinguished from the offence is not a `special reason` within the exception.
 
While it is impossible to enumerate or define everything that can amount to a special reason, one may give as an illustration a driver exceeding the speed limit because he has suddenly been called to attend a dying relative or a doctor going to an urgent call. So too it is certainly difficult to visualize what could amount to a special reason in the case of driving under the influence of drink or drugs, though perhaps one might be found if the court was satisfied that a drug had been administered to a driver without his knowledge, as for instance where a driver had taken a dose of medicine which he believed to be an ordinary tonic but which in fact contained a powerful drug. For myself, I would say that I strongly incline to the opinion that a person who drives or causes or permits a vehicle to be driven when there is no policy in force must be disqualified unless the court can find in relation to the particular offence some mitigating circumstance, and that mere forgetfulness or carelessness in not taking out a policy could not amount to a special reason.
 7.Goddard CJ`s construction of the phrase `special reasons` in 
 Whittall v Kirby 
 was followed not only in 
 Joseph Roland 
 and 
 Balasubramaniam 
 but also in numerous authorities for guidance on the construction of the phrase `special reasons`. The construction does not rob the court of discretion. It merely provides clear guidance as to the circumstances in which an offender is entitled, by law, for the mandatory disqualification to be dispensed with having regard to the facts of the offence. For example, the same English court some years later chose not to interfere with the magistrate`s decision to dispense with disqualification in 
Chapman v O`Hagan
 
[1949] 2 KB 690
 where the driver had taken drugs for a leg injury without knowing that it would make him more susceptible to the effect of alcohol. Closer to home, cases such as 
PP v M Karthiah
 
[1953] MLJ 52
 and 
Re Kanapathipillai
 
[1960] MLJ 243
 have followed 
 Whittall 
. The court in 
 M Karthiah 
 overturned the magistrate`s decision not to disqualify the appellant on the basis, stated at p 53 of the report, that `the appellant did not know of any other way of earning his livelihood other than driving a motor car`. Wilkinson J`s excerpt of Goddard CJ`s grounds at p 200 of the 
 Whittall 
 report is a fine example of the sound reasoning on which the judgment was founded. It read: 
It is to be observed that the sections are mandatory and that Parliament has provided that a period of disqualification shall be imposed but they have given a discretion to be exercised only for special reasons. The limited discretion must be exercised judicially. The reasons inducing the court to exercise it must be special, and special is the antithesis of general. The fact that a man is a first offender or that he has committed no motoring offence for many years are reasons of the most general character that can well be imagined. That a man is a professional driver cannot, as it seems to me, by any possibility be called a special reason. The fact that drivers are professional drivers would of itself indicate that they are more likely to be habitually on the roads than people who drive themselves, so there is all the more reason for protecting the public against them. By exercising discretion in favour of an offender because he is a professional driver it is obvious that the court is taking into account the fact that in such cases disqualification is likely to work greater financial hardship than in the case of a person who uses his car for social or casual purposes. There is no indication in the Act that Parliament meant to draw any distinction between drivers who earn their living by driving and any other users of motor cars Had Parliament intended that special consideration was to be shown to professional drivers or first offenders it would have so provided.
 8.The decision in 
 Karthiah 
 was followed in 
 Re Kanapathipillai 
, a case submitted by appellant`s previous counsel. Curiously enough 
 Re Kanapathipillai 
 was one of ten summons cases brought by the Deputy Public Prosecutor by way of criminal revision and for which Adams J took the opportunity to set out guidance for magistrates in the following terms (at p 243 H): 
Magistrates must appreciate that where there is a duty to disqualify a convicted person from holding a licence to drive a motor vehicle such duty falls not within the discretion of the convicting court but is imposed by the act of the legislature. This duty is not identified with the maximum punishment to be mitigated according to established principles. 
 The duty is mandatory but the act of the legislature has given a limited discretion to a convicting court, to be exercised judicially, to refrain from implementing the law`s clearly expressed requirement for a reason which is special to the offence but not for a reason special to the offender.
 [Emphasis is mine.]
 This passage noticeably resembled Goddard CJ`s statements in 
 Whittall v Kirby 
. Adams J then proceeded to discuss the reliance on 
 Whittall 
 in a number of local and English cases. Interestingly enough, he included the case of 
 Lim Kean Soo 
 in this list of cases. Although spelt differently, the case citation is the same as that of 
 Lim Kian Soo 
 submitted by counsel in this motion. In the absence of evidence to the contrary, it would not be impossible to infer that Adams J had considered 
 Lim Kean Soo 
 and concluded that the court there followed 
 Whittall 
. In any case, Adams J`s analysis was considered extensively and approved in the grounds of decision of the magistrate`s appeal from which this application arose. It was my view that over the years, the judgments made pointed to a consistent construction of `special reasons` on the basis of Goddard CJ`s ruling in 
 Whittall 
. This decision has clearly withstood the test of time and for good reason. It is clear from case history that consideration of the 
 Whittall 
 judgment inevitably led to the decision being upheld and contributed to a healthy examination of the reasons to support such a construction.
 9.In this regard, I refer to the decision of Thomson CJ in ordering mandatory disqualification in 
PP v Mohd Isa
 
[1963] MLJ 135
 where he made several useful observations. The appellant had pleaded guilty to a charge of permitting an unlicensed person to drive his motor-cycle and of allowing his motor-cycle to be used while an insurance policy was not in force. The magistrate had refrained from making a disqualification order on the ground that the offender required the use of his motor-cycle to get to his place of work; that he had many dependants to support and that he was a sick man. Thomson CJ reminded magistrates that for `special reasons` to dispense with the mandatory disqualification order, they had to be connected with the commission of the offence. With circumspect grace, he noted that there may be a certain amount of misunderstanding because some statements of the law have been over academic and metaphysical. Yet the statutory intention in mandating disqualification remained intact given his experience that the most satisfactory penalty for most motoring offences was disqualification because a fine is paid once and then forgotten. In his view, a disqualification meant that for 365 days the accused person is reminded every morning of his offence and so where an order for disqualification is made, except in serious cases of being drunk in charge or dangerous driving, the quantum of the monetary penalty imposed was of relatively minor importance. 
 Whittall 
 was applied again in 
PP v Hiew Chin Fong
 
 
[1988] 1 MLJ 467
  and the construction appreciated for the reasons that the offence is not to be taken lightly. If an innocent road user is knocked down and injured or killed, he and/or his dependants may have no means of recovering from the uninsured driver any loss or damage he and/or they may have suffered or sustained. It is clear from these authorities that to construe special reasons as being those connected with the offence and not the offender would be the clearest means of giving effect to Parliament`s intention. Parliament could not have intended an offender to be excused from the mandatory punishment by virtue of circumstances unique to his situation but irrelevant to the commission of the offence. The mandatory punishment is designed to take away the right that was abused in committing the offence.
 10.Against the weight of authority upholding 
 Whittall 
, counsel for the appellant submitted 
 R v Lim Kian Soo 
 as a decision inclined to a contrary construction of `special reasons`, thereby arguably creating a conflict of authority that necessitated reference to the Court of Criminal Appeal. In
 Lim 
, Murray-Aynsley CJ considered 
 Whittall 
 to bear persuasive as opposed to binding authority on the court and was of the opinion that Goddard CJ`s guidance in 
 Whittall 
 were open to objection in that they cut down on the discretion given to the courts. He expressed concern that circumstances of a personal nature may sometimes be valid and held that the matter should be treated as a question of discretion. Counsel for the appellant submitted that the decision in 
 Lim 
 was of binding authority on the basis of the stare decisis doctrine discussed in 
Young v Bristol Aeroplane Co Ltd
 
[1944] 2 All ER 293
: that, subject to three exceptions, courts are bound to follow previous decisions of its own as well as those of courts of a co-ordinate jurisdiction. He argued that the judgment of the court in 
 Lim 
, being a High Court sitting with three judges on a special case, was binding on the High Court hearing the appellant`s appeal in MA 198/97.
 11.With respect, the Singapore court`s position on this doctrine is well founded in the decision of the Court of Criminal Appeal in 
Mah Kah Yew v PP
 [1971] MLJ 1 [1969-1971] SLR 441 , and upheld in 
Wong Hong Toy v PP
 [1994] 3 SLR 396 . In 
Wong Hong Toy v PP
 
 
[1986] 2 MLJ 336
  
[1986] SLR 86
 , this jurisdiction`s well-known doctrine of precedents was confirmed in that the High Court is not bound by a previous decision of a High Court judge. Counsel contended that in the interests of promoting certainty, courts sitting in their appellate capacity should be bound by their own decisions. While in agreement with this principle, I had regard to the advice of the court in 
Chan Hiang Leng Colin v PP
 
 
[1995] 1 SLR 687
  that in the interest of maintaining finality in proceedings, it was better to exercise a discretion to refer sparingly so that the references are not used as an indirect way of appealing against matters that under the law have been finally determined by the High Court. I found this application to be one such veiled appeal. The court is not faced with so many vastly differing views as to suggest there is a rift in the authorities. I did not find the question so exceptional as to require reference; in fact, a glance at the many authorities upholding 
 Whittall 
 demonstrates that this was a common question before the High Court hearing appeals from the magistrate`s courts. It has clearly been authoritatively laid down and consistently applied by the courts here and, in the circumstances, there is no conflict of authority: 
PP v Bridges Christopher
 
 
[1997] 2 SLR 217
 .
 12.Finally, counsel submitted that the question sought to be referred was of public interest because its definition bore far-reaching implications in view of the use of the phrase in other statutory provisions. I could not agree. If one examined the other contexts in which the phrase `special reasons` was employed, for example, in s 21A(1) of the Environmental Public Health Act, it became clear that the 
 Whittall 
 construction did not necessarily apply to all occasions for which Parliament had chosen to legislate for special circumstances. This is clear from the decision of the court in 
PP v Lim Niah Liang
 
 [1997] 1 SLR 535 
 which held that `special reasons` permitted the court to exercise some discretion in deciding whether or not to sentence a physically disabled offender to carry out a corrective work order. The use of the phrase there relates to the viability and effectiveness of meting out such specific sentences as provided by the EPHA. That application can safely be distinguished from the question raised in this motion.
 13.
 Conclusion
I found it timely, almost half a century after Murray-Aynsley CJ`s remarks in 
 Lim Kian Soo 
, to confirm the construction laid out in 
 Whittall 
 and thereafter followed in numerous authorities. Accordingly, there was no conflict of authority on any question to be worthy of referral to the Court of Criminal Appeal.

title: Sriekaran s/o Thanka Samy v Public Prosecutor [1998] SGHC 252
content:
Sriekaran s/o Thanka Samy v Public Prosecutor
[1998] SGHC 252
 
 
Case Number
 
:
 
MA 63/1998
 
 
 
Decision Date
 
:
 
22 July 1998
 
 
 
Tribunal/Court
 
:
 
High Court
 
 
 
Coram
 
:
 
 
Yong Pung How CJ
 
 
 
 
Counsel Name(s)
 
:
 
 SK Kumar (SK Kumar & Associates) for the appellant; Amarjit Singh (Deputy Public Prosecutor) for the respondent 
 
 
 
Parties
 
:
 
 Sriekaran s/o Thanka Samy — Public Prosecutor 
 
 
 
Road Traffic
  – 
Offences
  – 
Driving without valid insurance
  – 
Sentencing
  – 
Disqualification order
  – 
Whether any special reasons to justify dispensing with mandatory disqualification order
  – 
s 3(2) Motor Vehicles (Third- Party Risks and Compensation) Act (Cap 189)
 
 
 
 
Judgment:
 
 
 
 
YONG PUNG HOW CJ
 The appellant was charged with driving motor car SBP 9320 J while there was not in force a policy of insurance in respect of third-party risk, an offence under s 3(1) Motor Vehicles (Third-Party Risks Compensation) Act (Cap 189) (MVA). He was convicted and fined $600 and sentenced to one year disqualification for all classes. The appellant paid the fines but appealed against the disqualification order. I dismissed his appeal and now give my reasons.
 2.
 Background
On 5 March 1998 the appellant`s car was involved in an accident along with two other vehicles at the Whampoa East junction of Serangoon Road. Investigations revealed that the appellant drove his vehicle without valid insurance coverage. The insurance policy for the car had expired approximately 3 months and 21 days before the date of the accident. The appellant pleaded guilty to the offence charged but contended that there were special reasons on the facts of his offence that justified dispensing with the mandatory disqualification order prescribed by s 3(2) of the MVA. The district judge found it incredulous that the appellant had continued driving his car without bothering to verify his cheque or that he was properly insured. He held that the appellant`s omission to do so could not be a special reason not to be disqualified.
 3.
 The appeal
Before me, counsel for the appellant submitted that the circumstances leading to the offence, if exceptional, could amount to special reasons. The defence was that at the material time, the appellant held a belief that the car was validly insured against third party risks. It is clear, following 
Knowler v Rennison
 
[1947] KB 488
, that the facts must show not only that the belief was innocent but that it was based on reasonable grounds. I could find no reasonable ground for such a belief on the facts before me. In fact, given that the appellant`s first cheque had been dishonoured, and hence no valid insurance coverage applied to his car, it would have been reasonable to expect the appellant to ensure his second cheque was properly processed if indeed he genuinely sought to be covered by insurance. He made no effort to do so.
 4.The policy behind the 12 months mandatory disqualification of s 3(2) MVA was considered in 
Stewart Ashley James v PP
 
 
[1996] 3 SLR 426
  which found it to be the deterrence of vehicles being used in circumstances endangering the user and other persons on the road, leaving such persons without compensation should the user not be able to satisfy the judgment. More recently, I examined the authorities which dealt with the present offence in 
MV Balakrishnan v PP
 (Unreported) and discussed what amounted to `special reasons` within the meaning of s 3(2). The law is clear that the reason must be special to the offence, not the offender: 
Re Kanapathipillai
 
[1960] MLJ 243
 . On the facts before me, I found no reason special to the offence to dispense with mandatory disqualification. It would appear that had the accident not occurred, the appellant would have continued driving around Singapore with the excuse that he had not received any notice that his insurance had lapsed. To permit road users to escape with such irresponsible conduct would go against the policy behind the enactment and would be an abuse of the legislature`s leniency accorded to cases where genuine special reasons exist.
 5.On the appellant`s own facts, it did not go unnoticed that his counsel`s submission of his being `not without means` was supported by an Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore statement of account accompanied by a demand note dated 21 March 1998 informing the appellant that a 5% penalty had been imposed on his overdue income tax. It was clear to me that this appellant could not be of sufficient means to be a road user should he continue to fail meeting payments. In all the circumstances of his case, I found no merit to his appeal. It was dismissed and the disqualification order upheld.

title: Lee Tiaw Chwee v Public Prosecutor [1998] SGHC 262
content:
Lee Tiaw Chwee v Public Prosecutor
[1998] SGHC 262
 
 
Case Number
 
:
 
MA 262/1997
 
 
 
Decision Date
 
:
 
01 August 1998
 
 
 
Tribunal/Court
 
:
 
High Court
 
 
 
Coram
 
:
 
 
Yong Pung How CJ
 
 
 
 
Counsel Name(s)
 
:
 
 Harbajan Singh (Daisy Yeo & Co) for the appellant; David Khoo (Deputy Public Prosecutor) for the respondent 
 
 
 
Parties
 
:
 
 Lee Tiaw Chwee — Public Prosecutor 
 
 
 
Criminal Procedure and Sentencing
  – 
Appeal
  – 
Appeal against conviction
  – 
Factual grounds of appeal
  – 
Trial judge's findings of fact
  – 
Trial judge entitled to prefer evidence of prosecution witnesses over that of defence
  – 
Trial judge satisfied that appellant failed to rebut prosecution's case
  – 
Whether findings of fact by trial judge so unreasonable as to warrant overruling by appellate court
 
 
Criminal Procedure and Sentencing
  – 
Identification parade
  – 
Whether evidence on identification parades reliable
  – 
Accused wore own clothes while others wore police pants and shoes at parade
  – 
Accused picked on basis of their faces rather than clothes
 
 
Criminal Procedure and Sentencing
  – 
Sentencing
  – 
Enhancement of sentence
  – 
Rioting
  – 
Aggravating factors
  – 
Appellant's age
  – 
Lack of provocation
  – 
Injury caused to victim
  – 
Prior convictions
  – 
Whether sentence manifestly inadequate
 
 
 
 
Judgment:
 
 
 
 1.
YONG PUNG HOW CJ
 
 Introduction
This was an appeal against the decision of the district judge in the subordinate court. He found the appellant together with four others guilty of rioting under s 147 of the Penal Code (Cap 224). All the accused were sentenced to 18 months` imprisonment and four strokes of the cane on the rioting charge. The appellant appealed against both his conviction and sentence on the rioting charge.
 2.
 The charge
The appellant was charged that he (and four others) on 23 March 1997, at or about 2.40am, in front of the Specialist Shopping Centre (SSC), Somerset Road, Singapore, together with two other unknown male persons, were members of an unlawful assembly, the common object of which was to cause hurt to one Ong Kay Wei, male 18 years old and, in the prosecution of such common object, violence was used and he had thereby committed an offence of rioting punishable under s 147 of the Penal Code.
 3.
 The facts
The facts of the case were largely not in dispute. The incident occurred at the SSC on the left side of Somerset Road facing the direction of Takashimaya Shopping Centre, just opposite Club 97. A group of four young motorcyclists, three with pillions, were riding along Somerset Road, at about 2.30am on 22 March 1997. PW1, Ong Kay Koon, rode one of the motorcycles with his friend PW2 riding pillion. The victim, PW1`s brother, Ong Kay Wei (PW3) was riding alone.
 4.When they were riding along Somerset Road, PW1 received a page from his house and he signalled his friends to stop opposite Club 97, SSC on the left side of the road. They all stopped their motorcycles while PW1 made a call on his handphone.
 5.Two men dashed across the road in front of Club 97, shouting vulgar words. One of the men flicked a cigarette butt at the motorcyclists. Three motorcyclists, including PW1, rode off. PW3 could not start his motorcycle and was set upon by the two men who had crossed the road, followed by four or five other men.
 6.PW3 was assaulted by the group and suffered multiple abrasions and a laceration. The other three motorcyclists managed to ride away but PW1 later returned to the scene. A group of four policemen who were on patrol in the SSC vicinity saw the assault and chased the assailants. They were assisted by another group of five policemen in a patrol car in front of the SSC. The five accused, including the appellant, were arrested.
 7.Two identification parades were held at the police station subsequently. PW1, PW2 and PW3 were able to identify the appellant at the identification parade.
 8.
 The prosecution`s case
The evidence adduced by the prosecution was mainly as follows. PW1 and PW2 were eyewitnesses to the assault of PW3. PW1 had identified the appellant as the man who had thrown the cigarette butt at the motorcyclists. He also pointed out the appellant as one of the first two men who had shouted vulgarities at the motorcyclists and was one of the first who had crossed the road to where PW3 was, to assault him. PW1 also picked out the appellant at an identification parade conducted at Tanglin Police Station.
 9.PW2 was slower on the scene than PW1. He also postively identified the appellant as the man who had thrown the cigarette butt. This corroborated PW1`s evidence that the appellant was one of the first two persons who were on the corridor and the road. He also picked out the appellant at the identification parade.
 10.The victim, PW3, also identified the appellant as the man who threw the cigarette butt. He testified that he saw the group of about six men move towards him and, as he was so nervous staring at them, he was unable to start his motorcycle. He saw the first two men clearly and identified one of them as the appellant. He further related how the appellant had grabbed hold of his neck from the back and kicked his motorcycle. His motorcycle fell and leaned on PW3 and also the appellant`s leg causing it to be trapped. Only when someone shouted `police` did the group stop attacking him and start to run. PW3 had identified the appellant at the scene. He also identified the appellant at the police parade.
 11.
 The defence case
The defence was that the appellant had been mistakenly identified as being one of the attackers. The appellant claimed that he had been to Club 97 with another accused B1 and had left when the club closed. He was merely standing outside waiting for a taxi. He also claimed that he was so drunk that he was not aware of what was going on around him. The defence claimed that this was a case of mistaken identity as the appellant did not know the other three accused who were also involved in the fracas.
 12.The prosecution applied to impeach the appellant`s credit by using the statement he gave to PW10 under s 121 of the Criminal Procedure Code (Cap 68) (CPC). The district judge found a material discrepancy between the statement he gave and his testimony at the stand and allowed the DPP to impeach his credit.
 13.The statement taken by PW10 contradicted his statement in court. In the statement, the appellant stated that he had been joined at the club by some friends and, when the club closed, had walked out with Ah Chai (B1) and a few friends. He later claimed that he never said that and that he had walked out only with B1.
 14.The appellant claimed that he was neither the one who flicked the cigarette butt at the motorcyclists nor the one who was involved in the fracas. In support of his case that it was one of mistaken identity, he relied on the fact that it was late at night and the prosecution witnesses were some distance away. As such, he claimed that they were unable to see the assailants clearly.
 15.The defence pointed out inconsistencies in the prosecution witnesses such as the fact that they were unable to point out the exact number of attackers. He also pointed out that there were discrepancies between the defence`s version of how the appellant had been arrested and the prosecution`s version.
 16.The defence also relied on the medical reports. They claimed that the fact that the appellant had not suffered any injury was inconsistent with PW3`s claim that the appellant had been the one who had assaulted him and the motorcycle had fallen down on him as well as the appellant. Further, PW3`s medical report showed no injury to his neck and this contradicted his claim that the appellant had grabbed him by the neck.
 17.
 The decision of the trial judge
The trial judge found the appellant guilty and convicted him on the rioting charge. He based his conviction on the identification evidence of the prosecution witnesses (PW1, PW2 and PW3) at the scene, and on the identification parades as well as in court. In convicting the appellant, he disbelieved the appellant`s defence of mistaken identity. He found that the appellant`s credibility had been impeached. As such, the appellant was to be disbelieved that he had left the club only with B1. Instead, he accepted the appellant`s earlier statement as evidence to the effect that four or five of his friends had joined him at the table in the Club that he had left the Club with B1 and a few other friends that day.
 18.He found that the group including the appellant had the common object to cause hurt to the victim. This common object was formed on the spot when they rushed as a group across the road to attack him. Although the appellant and another member of the group had reached the victim first, whereas the others were one or two metres behind, it could not be said that they did not form a group when they had dashed across and assaulted PW3. Whether or not the group members had a common intention to hurt PW3 was irrelevant ( 
Lim Thian Hor v PP
 
 
[1996] 2 SLR 258
 ). The trial judge also found that, in order to hold so, there need not necessarily be proof that all the members of the unlawful assembly must know each other.
 19.After considering all the evidence against the appellant, the version given by the appellant and the submissions of defence counsel, the trial judge was satisfied that the defence had not managed to rebut the prosecution`s case that the appellant was a member of the unlawful assembly, the common object of which was to cause hurt to PW3 and that, in the prosecution of their common object, PW3 was assaulted and hurt by them. As such, he decided that the appellant was guilty beyond reasonable doubt and convicted him on the rioting charge.
 20.
 Issues arising in the appeal
The appellant appealed against both his conviction and sentence. At the outset, it should be noted that the grounds of appeal relied upon by the appellant were primarily factual.
 21.In my opinion, the trial judge, as the trier of fact, had the benefit of observing the demeanour of both the prosecution and defence witnesses. He was entitled to prefer the evidence of the prosecution witnesses over that of the defence. The Court of Appeal in 
Ng Soo Hin v PP
 
 
[1994] 1 SLR 105
  had held that an appellate court will not disturb findings of fact unless they are clearly reached against the weight of the evidence. In examining the evidence, an appellate court has always to bear in mind that it has neither seen nor heard the witnesses and has to pay due regard to the trial judge`s findings and his reasons therefor. This was also reaffirmed in the case of 
Sundara Moorthy Lankatharan v PP
 
 
[1997] 3 SLR 464
 .
 22.Here, the trial judge considered the evidence of both the prosecution witnesses and the appellant at length. He was satisfied that the appellant had not managed to rebut the prosecution`s case that the appellant was a member of the unlawful assembly, the common object of which was to cause hurt to PW3 and that in the prosecution of the common object, PW3 was assaulted and hurt by them.
 23.In my opinion, the findings of fact by the trial judge were not so unreasonable as to warrant an overruling by an appellate court.
 
 Appeal against conviction
A Contradictory evidence of prosecution witnesses on number of attackers
 24.One of the grounds of appeal was that the trial judge erred in not properly considering and weighing the contradictory evidence of the prosecution witnesses on the number of attackers. In my opinion, this was not a valid ground of appeal. There was no material discrepancy in the evidence of the prosecution witnesses with regard to the number of attackers. The general consensus was that there were more than six persons assaulting PW3. PW1 and PW2 saw six to seven attackers, PW3 testified that about five to six persons assaulted him. The police witnesses gave essentially the same evidence.
 25.It is true that the prosecution witnesses were unable to give the exact number of persons who attacked PW3 at the material time. This was hardly surprising seeing that they had observed the event from different places and at different times. PW1 was riding his motorcycle away from the scene and had turned his head away to look at his brother, PW3. PW2 was riding pillion on PW1`s motorcycle and had turned around as well to look at the scene. As for the police witnesses, they were some distance away from the scene and had only started running towards the scene when they were alerted to the fracas.
 26.Under such circumstances, it was hardly surprising that there was a discrepancy in the evidence of the prosecution as to the number of attackers. In 
Chean Siong Guan v PP
 [1969] MLJ 63 , Abdul Hamid J stated that: 
 Discrepancies may, in my view, be found in any case for the simple reason that no two persons can describe the same thing in exactly the same way. Sometimes what appears to be discrepancies are in reality different ways of describing the same thing, or it may happen that the witnesses who are describing the same thing might have seen it in different ways and at different times and that is how discrepancies are likely to arise. These discrepancies may either be minor or serious discrepancies. Absolute truth is, I think beyond human perception and conflicting versions of an incident, even by honest and disinterested witnesses is a common occurrence. In weighing the testimony of witnesses, human fallibility in observation, retention and recollection are often recognised by the court. Being a question of fact, what a magistrate needs to do is to consider the discrepancies and say whether they are minor or serious discrepancies
 This view was endorsed by the learned Chief Justice in the case of 
PP v Kalpanath Singh
 
 
[1995] 3 SLR 564
 .
 27.The trial judge was entitled to come to the conclusion that this was a minor discrepancy and I was of the same opinion. The crux of the matter was that the totality of evidence showed that the five persons who were arrested on that day were members of the group who had attacked PW3. As such, it should not matter that there were inconsistencies in the prosecution witnesses as to the number of attackers.
 B Quality of the identification evidence
 28.Another ground of appeal by the appellant was that the appellant had been wrongly identified. This was in fact the gist of the appeal. In support of this ground, counsel for the appellant raised several points.
 (i) Inadequate lighting
 29.He pointed out that the incident happened at about 2.40am in the night, and hence the prosecution witnesses would not have been able to identify the attackers as the place would be dark at that time. At the trial, evidence by way of some 20 photographs taken by DW6 (the defence counsel`s secretary) was adduced. These photographs showed that the vicinity of the place where the incident took place was dark at night.
 30.However, the trial judge had considered DW6`s evidence carefully and concluded that the photographs taken by DW6 were unreliable. In coming to this conclusion, the trial judge took into consideration the fact that DW6 had not taken any courses on photography and that the photos taken may not have been an adequate reflection of the actual conditions at the scene. In particular, DW6 had conceded that the area was not as dark as it had appeared in the photographs. DW6 had also testified that there were street lamps in the vicinity. Further, there could well be other factors contributing to the darkness of the photographs.
 31.I note that the evidence of PW1 and PW6 that the place was well-lighted was not challenged at all at the trial. As such, the trial judge was justified in accepting PW1 and PW6`s evidence that the area was well-lighted and, as such, they and the other prosecution witnesses could see what they had testified to in court.
 (ii) Contradictory evidence on the existence of steps
 32.The evidence of the prosecution witnesses was that there were steps leading from the corridor to the pavement. In reality, there were no steps. As such, counsel for the appellant submitted that the evidence on the identification of the appellant on how he had climbed down the steps and moved to the pavement to attack PW3 became suspect. Therefore the trial judge erred in not properly considering and weighing this in convicting the appellant based on the identification evidence of the prosecution witnesses.
 33.There is no indication that the trial judge did not properly consider this discrepancy. He realised that PW1, PW2 and PW3 had testified that the attackers had used the steps to move from the corridor to the pavement. However, he concluded that these witnesses must have been mistaken about the steps as no photographs were shown to them.
 34.Further, as the trial judge rightfully pointed out, the error in the evidence of the prosecution witnesses relating to the existence of the steps or staircase was not a material one. What was material was that the `movement of the group from the corridor down to the kerb, down to the road is something seen by these six prosecution witnesses`. As such, this minor discrepancy would not affect the credibility of PW1, PW2 and PW3.
 (iii) Contradictory evidence of prosecution witnesses in identifying the attackers
 35.The trial judge, in my opinion, had carefully considered the relevant evidence. In relation to PW1, he was cross-examined extensively by the appellant`s counsel but PW1 maintained that, when he first heard the shouting, he had already seen the faces of the men standing outside Club 97. He observed them for a period of one to three minutes. He saw one of them smoking and throwing a cigarette butt at the motorcyclists. He could identify that one of the two men who had dashed out first was the appellant. When he rode off on his motorcycle, he passed by the group and again had the opportunity to look at them. He then looked behind him and saw a group of about six or seven persons assaulting PW3. PW1 could identify the five accused as part of the group of persons who had assaulted PW3. At the scene and at the identification parades, he could also identify the appellant as one of the persons who had assaulted the appellant. The trial judge considered that it was clear that PW1 had relied on a sequence spanning more than one to three minutes to base his identification of the five accused.
 36.As for PW2, he stated that he had a good look at the faces of the attackers when they were at the corridor, at the steps and on the road. He had turned back as PW1 rode off on his motorcycle. Although PW2 could not recognise all the attackers, he was sure that the appellant was involved in the attack as it was the appellant who had thrown a cigarette butt at him and his friends. PW2 managed to identify the appellant at the scene as well as at the identification parades.
 37.PW3 gave evidence that the appellant was one of the attackers. He went into considerable detail as to the manner in which the appellant had assaulted him. He also identified the appellant at the scene and at the identification parades.
 38.As such, all the three prosecution witnesses were able to identify the appellant as being the person who had first dashed across the road and attacked PW3. PW2 and PW3 could also identify the appellant as the person who had thrown a cigarette butt in their direction. Therefore, as far as the identification of the appellant by the prosecution witnesses was concerned, I was of the view that there were no discrepancies in their evidence.
 C Medical reports
 39.A further ground of appeal was that the medical evidence was inconsistent with the prosecution witnesses` evidence. PW3 testified that the appellant had grabbed him by the neck from behind. However, the medical examination report showed no sign of injury on his neck. Further, the doctor (PW4) testified that, during the examination, PW3 had not complained about his neck. In my opinion, the district judge was correct to hold that this was not fatal to PW3`s evidence that he was grabbed by the appellant by the neck. Whether he would suffer from any physical injury would depend on the manner and the amount of force used by the appellant when he grabbed PW3`s neck. Further, the fact that PW3 had not complained to PW4 about his neck was not surprising when the other injuries he was suffering from were considered multiple abrasions over the right shoulder, upper chest and elbow. Since he was not injured around the neck, it made perfect sense that he did not complain about his neck.
 40.The appellant also argued that the trial judge erred in not considering and weighing that no injuries were detected on the appellant at all. I did not see how the trial judge erred in this. The appellant had attacked the victim with four other persons. With five persons hitting PW3, he could hardly retaliate. Thus, it was hardly surprising that the appellant managed to walk off without a single scratch on him. Further, the appellant argued that, since PW3 had alleged that the motorcycle had fallen down and pinned the appellant`s leg, there should be evidence of injury. The trial judge had considered this and noted that PW3 had also stated that the motorcycle had fallen on him as well as the appellant. It may be that the motorcycle had fallen down harder on PW3 and he thus bore the brunt of the fall. Also, whether the appellant would suffer from any injury would depend on the force and manner the appellant`s leg was pinned under the motorcycle.
 D Evidence of the witnesses at the identification parades
 41.Counsel for the appellant submitted that the evidence on the identification parades was unreliable as the accused were wearing their own pants and shoes while the other people in the parades were dressed in police pants and shoes. He submitted that the `consequences in law are very serious if one were to accept the accuracy of such identification parades`. In my opinion, the trial judge had considered carefully the evidence and was entitled to draw the conclusion that he drew, based on the evidence adduced before him. He had noted that PW1, PW2 and PW3 had testified that they had picked out the respective accused persons according to their faces and not their jeans. He noted that, had they been influenced by or relied on the jeans or pants worn by the accused instead of their faces to pick out each of them, they could have identified all the five accused at the two parades. Instead, PW1 had identified only four accused, B2 to B5. PW2 identified three accused, B1, B2 and B4. PW3 also identified B2 to B5. The trial judge stated: 
Although it was proper for all the paraders to be similarly attired, the identification of the five accused were not based on their different attire. I was convinced beyond any reasonable doubt that all five accused were members of the group which assaulted PW3. My finding was not solely based on the identifications made at the parades. However, the identifications at the parades, at the scene and in court formed part of the evidence I had relied on.
 E Impeachment of appellant`s credit
 42.The appellant confirmed that he had given the statement P24 freely without any threat against him. He could not give any reason why PW10 would substitute a different version from what he had stated. When the appellant was confronted with the discrepancy between the highlighted portion of P24, namely, `
 We were joined by another four to five friends at our table I walked out with Ah Chai and a few friends 
`, and his evidence in court, namely, that he was not joined by anyone at Club 97 and that he had left Club 97 with only B1, he stated that he did not know how to explain the contradiction.
 43.In these circumstances, the trial judge was correct in holding that the appellant`s credit had been impeached. He found that, as the statement had been taken only two days after the incident which occurred on 22 March 1996, the incident should still be fresh in the appellant`s mind. Thus, his recollection should be better on 25 March 1996 than on 28 August 1997, when he gave evidence. He could also find no conceivable reason why PW10 would, at the risk of losing his job, substitute his own version for what the accused had told him.
 44.
 Conclusion
The trial judge had clearly identified all the issues which the defence raised during this appeal, considered them, and still found that the prosecution had proved their case beyond reasonable doubt. In my opinion, the trial judge was right in holding so. There may be a few inconsistencies in the evidence of the prosecution witnesses but they were minor discrepancies. Accordingly I was of the view that the appeal should be dismissed.
 45.
 Sentence
In reviewing the sentence, I was drawn to conclude that the sentence of 18 months` imprisonment and four strokes of the cane was manifestly inadequate. Not only were there no mitigating factors in favour of reducing the sentence, there were serious aggravating factors in the appellant`s conduct.
 46.PW3 was only 18 years old whereas the appellant was 32 years old at that time. Furthermore, PW3 had done nothing to provoke the appellant and the appellant had just set upon PW3 together with another four or five other people. They had rained continuous blows and kicks upon him. The appellant also had previous convictions (one for gaming in public and another for consumption of drugs). The medical report was that PW3 had suffered `multiple abrasions over the right shoulder, upper chest, mild abrasion over the right elbow that was bleeding from the subdermal vessels with surrounding mild elbow swelling and tenderness on movement`.
 47.Accordingly I enhanced the appellant`s sentence to 24 months` imprisonment and six strokes of the cane.

title: Rav IE v Public Prosecutor [1987] SGHC 25
content:
Rav IE v Public Prosecutor
[1987] SGHC 25
 
 
Case Number
 
:
 
MA 35/1987
 
 
 
Decision Date
 
:
 
01 July 1987
 
 
 
Tribunal/Court
 
:
 
High Court
 
 
 
Coram
 
:
 
 
Chua F A J
 
 
 
 
Counsel Name(s)
 
:
 
 Jeanny Ng (Jeanny Ng) for the appellant; David Khoo (Deputy Public Prosecutor) for the respondent 
 
 
 
Parties
 
:
 
 Rav IE — Public Prosecutor 
 
 
 
Criminal Procedure and Sentencing
  – 
Sentencing
  – 
Causing death of passenger by driving car in manner dangerous to the public
  – 
Whether imprisonment mandatory
  – 
Whether sentence manifestly excessive
  – 
s 67(1) Road Traffic Act (Cap 92, 1970 Ed)
 
 
Cur Adv Vult
 
The appellant, Rav Ie @ Raghavan Iyengar, appeals against the sentence of three months` imprisonment and three years` disqualification from holding all classes of driving licence, imposed by the district court when he was convicted on a charge of causing the death of a passenger in his car by driving the motor car in a manner which was dangerous to the public, an offence under s 67(1) of the Road Traffic Act (Cap 92). The appellant had pleaded guilty to the charge.
On 20 July 1985, the appellant drove along Tanglin Road at a fast speed and encroached on the wrong side of the road when negotiating a bend, and collided with an on-coming taxi. As a result of the collision the rear passenger in his car was killed on the spot. The certified cause of death was: asphyxia due to aspiration of food.
The trial judge was of the view that s 67(1) prescribed a mandatory sentence of up to five years` imprisonment and that it did not provide for a fine as punishment.
The main point raised in the appeal is whether imprisonment is mandatory under s 67(1). The provision is that a person guilty of an offence under s 67(1) `shall be liable on conviction to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years`.
Counsel for the appellant relied on the Malaysian case of 
 PP v Man b Ismail 
 
 
 
[1939] MLJ 207
  where the words `shall be liable` were construed by Aitken J. and where he held that `shall be liable to imprisonment` in s 3(a) of the Vagrants and Decrepit Persons Enactment (FMS Cap 191) did not render a sentence of imprisonment mandatory. He said (p 208): 
 
It would also seem that the learned magistrate, who tried this particular case, was under the impression that because the section provides that every person found guilty of an offence against it `shall be liable to imprisonment for six months`, therefore he was compelled to pass some sentence of imprisonment on such a person however many mitigating circumstances might be present. If that was his impression, then in my opinion he was under an entirely wrong impression as to the meaning of the words `shall be liable to`. To my mind they give the court an absolute discretion as to whether it shall award a sentence of imprisonment or deal with the accused under and in accordance with the probationary provisions of s 294 of the Criminal Procedure Code. If the legislature had intended that all persons convicted of an offence against this s 3(a) of the Vagrants and Decrepit Persons Enactment should be sent to prison, whatever the circumstances may be, it would have used the expression `shall be punished with imprisonment`, which is to be found so frequently in our Penal Code.
 
 
 
It is to be observed that Aitken J was there dealing with the question whether the court could deal with a person, who had been convicted of any offence punishable with imprisonment, under and in accordance with the probationary provisions of s 294 of the Criminal Procedure Code (FMS Cap 6). He was not dealing with the question of whether the court had a discretion to impose a fine in lieu of imprisonment.
In 
 PP v Hew Yew 
 
 
 
[1972] 1 MLJ 164
 , Raja Azlan Shah J also construed the words `shall be liable` in s 15(4) of the Prevention of Crime Ordinance 1959 of Malaysia, which reads: 
 
A registered person who contravenes or fails to comply with any order or restriction imposed on him under this section shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years and not less than two years.
 
 
 
The learned judge reviewed certain authorities on the words `shall be liable` therein. They show that where provisions of law provide for a term of imprisonment or an amount by way of fine, the courts have a discretion to impose a term of imprisonment or fine not exceeding the maximum prescribed. In the context of s 15(4) of the Prevention of Crime Ordinance, from the words `shall be liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years and not less than two years`, the learned Judge expressed this view (p 164): `From that it seems to me that the court has an absolute discretion to impose the maximum sentence of five years or any lesser sentence the minimum of which must not be less than two years.`
In the result, he set aside the sentence of a fine imposed by the lower court and substituted a sentence of two years` imprisonment.
In 
 Jayanathan v PP 
 
 
 
[1973] 2 MLJ 68
  the following question of law was referred to the Federal Court of Malaysia: 
 
Whether the provision of s 15(4) of Prevention of Crime Ordinance 1959 overrules the provision of s 294 of the Criminal Procedure Code in so far as an offence against s 15 of the Prevention of Crime Ordinance is committed.
 
 
 
In that case, the applicant had pleaded guilty to a charge of contravening a restriction order imposed on him under s 15 of the Prevention of Crime Ordinance 1959. The learned President bound him over in the sum of $1,000 in one surety under s 294 of the Criminal Procedure Code. The time for appeal having lapsed, the learned Deputy Public Prosecutor applied for revision of this order to the High Court on the ground that `the learned President erred in law in imposing a sentence of binding over when s 15(4) of the Ordinance clearly states `shall be liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years and not less than two years`.`
The Federal Court considered the cases of 
 PP v Hew Yew 
 
 
 
[1972] 1 MLJ 164
  and 
 PP v Man B Ismail 
 
 
 
[1939] MLJ 207
  and considered the provisions of s 294 of the Criminal Procedure Code (FMS Cap 6). Ong Hock Sim FJ delivering the judgment of the court said (p 69): 
 
This section (s 294) vests the court before which a person is convicted with power to suspend sentence for such period as the court may direct, and, if the offender behaves himself during such period, he would escape punishment for his offence. If he fails to observe the conditions of his bond, he would be liable to be apprehended and dealt with for his original offence. As Thomson J (as he then was) said in 
 PP v ldris
