Cur Adv Vult
 
This is an appeal from the judgment of Chan Sek Keong J. By that judgment, the learned judge awarded to the respondents the sum of US$339,822 with interest and costs on their claim against the appellants for damages for breach of contract to carry and deliver from Bangkok, Thailand, to Khorramshahr, Iran, a cargo of 5,450 bales of kenaf (`the goods`) which were shipped on board the appellants` vessel Kota Sejarah and/or for conversion of the goods and/or for breach of duty as bailees and/or for negligence.
The material facts that gave rise to the dispute have been set out in great detail by the learned judge in his judgment which was reported in 
 
 
[1991] 1 MLJ 136
  . For our purpose, it is necessary only to recount them briefly as follows. On 3 January 1979, the respondents shipped on board the appellants` vessel Kota Sejarah in Bangkok the goods under two clean bills of lading for carriage to Khorramshahr. The vessel sailed from Bangkok on 6 January 1979 and arrived at Basrah on or about 26 January; Basrah is situate across the Shatt al-Arab waterway from Khorramshahr. The vessel could not get into Khorramshahr to discharge the goods because of congestion at the waterway arising from stevedores` and port workers` strikes on account of the then political unrest in Iran. After waiting in Basrah for sometime, the appellants decided to invoke cl 5 of the bills of lading (to which we shall revert in detail in a moment) and they telexed their agent in Bangkok to inform the shippers of their decision as follows: 
 
In view of the condition now prevailing in Iran and stevedore strike at Khorramshahr which prevent discharge of cargoes carried under the above-mentioned bill of lading destined for Khorramshahr, owners hereby give notice that they are obliged to invoke cl 5 of the said bills of lading and accordingly are proceeding to discharge the said cargo at Mina Qaboos or any other convenient ports. You and all interested parties are hereby invited to make arrangements concerning storage and on carriage of the said cargo so discharged. The cargo owners are advised to insure the cargo pending on carriage if necessary.
 
 
 
On being informed of this, the respondents telexed the appellants seeking information on the itinerary of the vessel and were informed by telex that most likely the goods would be discharged at Porbander on the west coast of India. Later, the vessel did go to Porbander and the goods were discharged there and stored at the port godown. Subsequently, there were telexes exchanged between the appellants and the respondents. On 1 March 1979, the appellants telexed to the respondents in which, among other things, they inquired whether the respondents or `the receivers` wished to make their own arrangements for forwarding the goods to Khorramshahr or to arrange with their agent in India for the purpose and suggested that the `receivers` should effect insurance on their goods and at the same time they also asked what the `receivers` intended to do in regard to the on-forwarding of the goods and insurance. There was no response to this telex. However, on 6 March, one SM Gourisaria, a director of the respondents, went to Bombay and met one PJ Dalal, the manager of James Mackintosh & Co Ltd (`Mackintosh`), the appellants` agent in India. They had discussions on various matters relating to the goods. After that, Gourisaria went to other parts of India and returned to Bombay by the end of March where he met and discussed with PJ Dalal further; he returned to London at the beginning of April. Nothing developed out of such discussions, and the goods continued to be stored at the port godown in Porbander.
On 9 May 1979, the respondents tried unsuccessfully to telex to the appellants on the current position relating to the goods. On the following day, the respondents telexed to Mackintosh requesting them to pass the following message to the appellants, which Mackintosh did: 
 
Pls note that we as holders of the bills of lading referred to above hold entitlement to and are owners of the goods resulting from a situation in which our buyers have defaulted stop We are in process of selling these goods elsewhere and as such ask you to instruct your agents in India, James Mackintosh Co Pte Ltd, Bombay not to remove cargo without our written approval and if and when we are able to sell these goods we will then give them the necessary instructions for the appropriate release in yr favour or at our discretion stop Needless to say we will be responsible for storage charges in Porbandar. Kindly confirm.
 
 
 
The appellants replied on 11 May stating that it was too late to comply with the request as the goods had already been loaded onto the vessel Kota Agung which was scheduled to depart for Mina Qaboos on 14 May and from Mina Qaboos for Khorramshahr on 17 May, and that they would be prepared to unload the cargo at Mina Qaboos subject to certain terms and conditions. On receipt of this telex, the respondents telexed Mackintosh stating that they did not want the cargo to be loaded, and in response Mackintosh replied by telex stating that the cargo had been loaded and that the ship was sailing on the following day which was 12 May, and that the cargo could not be discharged even at the expense of the respondents. To that the respondents protested by telex and they also sent a telex to the appellants stating, among other things, that they insisted that the latter telexed to Bombay to off-load the cargo and `leave as it was where it was`. Further exchange of telexes took place, and on 24 May 1979, the parties reached an agreement, without prejudice to each other`s rights, to have the goods reshipped to Bangkok at an agreed rate. Unfortunately, an untoward event happened to the Kota Agung: after her arrival at Khorramshahr on 17 June 1979, she caught fire on 9 July in the course of unloading her cargoes, resulting in a total constructive loss of her cargoes on board, including the respondents` goods.
Thereafter, the respondents instituted an in rem action, Admiralty in Rem No 870 of 1980 against Kota Bakti, a sister ship of Kota Agung, claiming damages for breach of contract, and/or conversion of the goods and/or for breach of duty as bailees and/or for negligence. Following that, another cargo owner also instituted an in rem action, Admiralty in Rem No 387 of 1981, but that action was against Kota Sejarah, also a sister ship of Kota Agung, claiming for similar reliefs. Both the actions were subsequently consolidated. However, only the respondents pursued their claims at the trial, as the parties to the second action had come to a settlement.
Before Chan Sek Keong J, the parties had agreed on certain matters. First, it was accepted that the respondents were the owners of the goods at the time of the reloading at Porbander; secondly, the appellants had properly invoked cl 5 of the bills of lading, and lastly, that the Carriage of Goods by Sea Act (Cap 33) had no application to the transhipment of the goods. The following were the issues before the trial judge: 
 
 
(1) whether the appellants acted wrongfully in removing the goods from the port godown at Porbander and transhipping them on board the Kota Agung; 
 
(2) whether the removal and transhipment constitute conversion of the respondents` goods; and 
 
(3) alternatively, whether the appellants were in breach of duty as bailees and/or were negligent as a result of which the goods were lost by fire on board the Kota Agung.
  
 
 
The learned judge held that on the true construction of cl 5, the appellants having abandoned the voyage and discharged the goods at Porbander were not permitted under that clause to tranship the goods to Khorramshahr. On the second issue, he held that the respondents had a right to prohibit the transhipment of the goods and they exercised that right, and that as the appellants had no right to tranship the goods, the transhipment constituted conversion of the goods. The learned judge further held that the appellants had no right to retain possession of the goods on board the Kota Agung and the wrongful possession thereof constituted a trespass to the goods. The goods were lost whilst they were still in the possession of the appellants, and the appellants` position was that of an insurer and in the event that happened they were liable for the loss of the goods irrespective of whether or not they were negligent.
On the alternative claim for damages for breach of duty and/or negligence in the performance of the transhipment of the goods, the learned judge held that as the appellants were bailees of the goods, the onus was on them to establish that the goods were lost without their negligence and he found that the appellants had failed to discharge that onus. He was unable to find the cause of the fire but he found that the hatches remained open for three hours during the lunch break and that substantially increased the risks of fire occurring to the goods. In his view, since the fire was not caused by self-combustion or the heat of the sun either on the goods or the ship, it could only have been caused by an external source deliberately or accidentally. This source of fire was contemplated by the master. He found that the master of the ship was negligent or in breach of duty in failing to close the hatches during the lunch break and thereby increased the risks of fire occurring to the goods, and that in any event the appellants in failing to prove the probable cause of the fire had not discharged the onus of proving that their servants were not negligent. The learned judge then considered the defence relied upon by the appellants under s 271 of the Merchant Shipping Act (Cap 179) and held that the section had no application as the cargo was carried on board the ship without the consent of the owners of the goods.
Before us the issues raised are substantially the same as those that were raised below and may be restated as follows: 
 
 
(1) whether cl 5 of the bills of lading gave to the appellants the liberty to tranship the respondents` goods in the circumstances that occurred; 
 
(2) if the answer to the first issue is in the negative, whether the transhipment of the goods in the circumstances that occurred constituted a conversion of the goods; 
 
(3) alternatively, whether the appellants were in breach of duty as bailees of the goods and/or were negligent; and 
 
(4) whether the provisions of s 271 of the Merchant Shipping Act (Cap 179) applied to the goods of the respondents carried on board the Kota Agung.
  
 
 
The first issue turns essentially on the true construction of cl 5 of the bills of lading, which so far as relevant provides as follows: 
 
If the ... carriage discharge or delivery is impeded or if there are reasonable grounds for anticipating that the same is or threatens to be impeded by the imminence outbreak or existence of war ... or by ... lockouts strikes or disturbances ice bad weather or by absence from any cause of facilities for loading discharge or delivery or congestion or difficulties in loading or discharge, the carrier and/or his agents and/or the master may (if in his or their uncontrolled discretion he or they think it advisable) at any time before or after the commencement of the voyage abandon or suspend the voyage or alter or vary or depart from the proposed or advertised or agreed or customary route and/or delay or detain the vessel at or off any port or place and/or tranship and forward subject to the provisions of cl 11 hereof or put into bulk lighter or craft or land or store or otherwise dispose of the cargo at any port or ports place or places without being liable for any loss or damage whatsoever directly or indirectly sustained by the owners of the goods and all at the risk and expense of the owners of the goods. Anything done or not done by reason of or in compliance with the provisions hereinbefore contained or any of them shall be deemed to be within the contract voyage.
 
 
 
It is clear that cl 5 gave the appellants multiple liberties or options on the occurrence of any of the contingencies therein stipulated. It was accepted that the appellants, in the event that had occurred, were entitled to invoke cl 5 and that they had properly invoked cl 5. It was also accepted that in invoking cl 5 the appellants exercised the right of abandoning the voyage and they did abandon the voyage. They caused or directed the vessel to proceed to Porbander where the goods were discharged and stored at the port godown. The question that arises is whether having thus abandoned the voyage they were entitled, about two months later, to tranship the goods for on-carriage to Khorramshahr. Chan Sek Keong J held that the concept of abandonment of the voyage was inconsistent with that of transhipment and that as the appellants had abandoned the voyage and discharged the goods, they had fulfilled their part of the contract of carriage; they could not then tranship the goods. In other words, the contract had come to an end. Clause 5 could not be so construed as to give to the shipowners the two inconsistent alternatives. He said, at pp 142-143: 
 
... It is clear that cl 5 reserves to the defendants a number of options to take if the discharge of cargo is hindered by the occurrence of any of the prescribed events. The defendants may abandon the voyage, or suspend it or delay it. They may also discharge the cargo, presumably after an abandonment or a suspension of the voyage. They may also tranship the goods. However, the crucial question is whether the power to tranship the goods is cumulative with or alternative with the power to abandon the voyage. ... In my view, and having regard to the general law, cl 5 cannot be so construed. Such a construction will enable the defendants to decide on a conditional abandonment, a concept which will lead to great inconvenience to cargo owners. I am not aware of any authority giving effect to such a concept. If there is any doubt about the meaning of cl 5, it should be construed against the defendants. There is, I think, no inconsistency between the power to suspend or delay or alter the voyage and the power to tranship the cargo. This was not what the defendants purported to do. The voyage having come to an end at Porbander, there was nothing in cl 5 which gave the defendants the power to on-carry the goods to any other place.
 
 
 
Mr Isaac for the respondents supported this construction of cl 5. He submitted that under that clause the master may: 
 
 
(i) abandon the voyage, 
 or 
 
 
(ii) suspend the voyage, 
 or 
 
 
(iii) alter or vary or depart from the proposed or advertised or agreed or customary route, 
 and/or 
 
 
(iv) delay or detain the vessel at or off any port or place, 
 and/or 
 
 
(v) tranship and forward subject to the provisions of cl 11, 
 or 
 
 
(vi) put into bulk lighter or craft, 
 or 
 
 
(vii) land or store or otherwise dispose of the cargo at any port or ports, place or places.
  
 
 
In his submission, certain of the options available to the master are inconsistent with each other, and in particular the option (i) is mutually inconsistent with options (ii) and (iii); similarly option (i) is mutually inconsistent with option (iv), notwithstanding the conjunctions `and/or` preceding (iv). By the same reasoning, the option (i) is mutually inconsistent with option (v), also notwithstanding the conjunctions `and/or` preceding option (v). As a matter of language, the words `abandonment` and `transhipment` are not consistent with each other, and these words should be given their natural and ordinary meanings. At best, there is an ambiguity whether if the master has elected to abandon the voyage he still has the power to tranship the goods, and such ambiguity must be resolved in favour of the respondents. Accordingly, once the appellants had elected to abandon the voyage and had discharged the goods at Porbander, they had exhausted their rights under cl 5 and could not thereafter elect to tranship the goods for on-carriage to Khorramshahr. We find great merit in this submission and unhesitatingly accept it.
In the absence of any express liberty reserved or provided in a bill of lading the master has no general right to tranship goods carried on board his ship. The Australian case of 
 Barker v Burns Philp & Co Ltd 
 1 is instructive on this point. Under five bills of lading dated 8 December 1941, the plaintiffs shipped on board the defendants` vessel Mangola a cargo of wheat from Sydney to Singapore. The bills of lading contained conditions which, among other things, gave to the master various liberties. One of the liberties was that in the event of, inter alia, the imminence or existence of war, the master was empowered to depart from the agreed or customary route and/or discharge the cargo (for delivery or transhipment) at or off any port and when so discharged the carrier`s responsibility ceased and such discharge would constitute due delivery under the bills of lading. The ship sailed from Sydney on 13 December 1941 and joined a convoy sailing for Singapore. En route she called at Batavia (now Jakarta). Shortly after her arrival, Batavia was bombed twice and news of the fall of Singapore was received. Shore conditions at Batavia were chaotic and the master enquired from the naval authorities whether he could communicate with the owners and was informed that he could not as the army and navy had priority on all the lines. He made no further or other attempt to communicate with the owners. In particular, he did not try to communicate through the local wireless or cable office, although such communication was in fact possible. There was no prohibition against unloading the cargo in Batavia but no shore labour was available. The master was told to wait for the next convoy. He waited for a while and later took the ship back to Australia alone arriving first at Fremantle and subsequently the ship returned to Sydney with her cargoes. The defendants claimed half of the back freight to Sydney from the plaintiffs. The latter paid the freight under protest and instituted an action claiming the return of the back freight. The case was heard before Halse Rogers J who held that the defendants were entitled to full back freight to Fremantle and on that basis the defendants had not been overpaid, and he accordingly dismissed the claim. On appeal, the Supreme Court of New South Wales held by a majority that the defendants were not entitled to the back freight for the carriage of the goods back to Sydney. Jordan CJ in the course of his judgment said, at pp 17-18: 
 
I think that the proper inference from the evidence is that at Batavia the master ultimately decided to abandon the voyage. This he was entitled to do under the added condition No 2 on the front of the bill, a condition which authorizes him, when a state of war exists, either to abandon the voyage or to alter the route and proceed to the port of discharge by a different route. If he adopts the latter course he is performing the intended voyage in a varied but permitted manner. If the former, the voyage is abandoned, and the question arises as to what is to be done with the goods. No provision is made for this in the special added war provision. ... In my opinion, therefore, the position at Batavia was that the master was entitled, without reference to the owner of the goods, to land them there and also to abandon the voyage, if he thought this best in the interests of all parties, but that, he having abandoned the voyage, there was nothing in the bill of lading which entitled him to carry them to some other port without communicating to the owners of the goods (if it were reasonably possible to do so with a reasonable expectation of receiving a timely answer) such reasonably adequate information of the nature of the emergency and of the nature of, and reasons for, his proposed action, as it was reasonably possible for him to give, and obtaining their sanction. He was therefore not justified in taking the course which he did without instructions from them, unless (1) it was both necessary and reasonable so to carry the goods in what he might reasonably regard as the best interests of the shippers and (2) it was not reasonably possible for him to communicate with them, in circumstances giving a reasonable expectation that an answer would be received in time, or, if such communication was possible, and was had, no sufficient instructions were received in time to give him a reasonable opportunity of complying with them before it became necessary to act. In other words, I am of opinion that there is nothing in the bill of lading which takes the case out of the general law.
 
 
 
The learned Chief Justice examined the evidence as to whether it was possible for the master to communicate with the owners of the cargo with reasonable expectation of receiving a timely reply. There was ample evidence that the communications between Batavia and Sydney were in fact possible both by wireless and by cable. The learned Chief Justice therefore came to the conclusion that if the master had used due diligence, he could have taken advantage of the means of communication which were available and that the action of the master in carrying the goods back to Fremantle without instructions from the plaintiffs was unauthorized. Davidson J who dissented from the conclusion reached by the majority also held (at p 21) that the master had no express authority to bring back the goods at the expense of the shipper but held that the conditions then prevailing in Batavia justified the master bringing the cargoes back and accordingly the defendants were entitled to the full back freight to Fremantle. Street J agreed with Jordan CJ that the defendants were not entitled to the back freight but on different grounds. He held that on the true construction of the provisions of the bills of lading the master, although he had abandoned the voyage in Batavia, was entitled to bring the goods back to Sydney but the plaintiffs were not liable for the back freight. He said, at p 25: 
 
... If he had commenced the voyage, the master could decide at any moment, assuming such decision was bona fide, to abandon all intention of proceeding further and was to be entitled then, inter alia, to return to the port of shipment, land the goods and place them in store at the disposal of the owner subject to the payment by such owner of all landing and storage charges.
 
 
 
The right to return the goods to the port of shipment was available to the master in the present case under the express terms of the bill of lading. It is true that he had decided at Batavia to abandon the voyage originally contemplated by the terms of the bill of lading. ... But abandonment of the voyage does not mean the abandonment or destruction of the contract. The voyage had been broken off with the intention on the part of the master of relinquishing, finally and permanently, its further continuance to the originally designated port of destination. The possibility of such a situation arising had, it seems to me, been clearly foreseen by the parties and their contract makes provision to meet such an occasion. The master was then to have the right to land and store the goods at any intermediate port or might, if he so chose, return them to the port of shipment.
In our judgment, on the true construction of cl 5 of the bills of lading the appellants having abandoned the voyage were not authorized under cl 5 to tranship the goods at Porbander for on-carriage to Khorramshahr. Even if we are wrong on this construction and under cl 5 the appellants had such liberty of transhipment, they had elected not to exercise the right of transhipment at all. We find that on the evidence it is clear that in February 1979 when the appellants invoked cl 5 and abandoned the voyage they had no intention of effecting a transhipment of the goods, then or later. In fact, their telexes evinced their intention to the contrary. First, in their telex of 3 February they stated that they had been obliged to invoke cl 5; that they were proceeding to discharge the cargoes at Mina Qaboos or any other convenient ports; that the cargo owners were invited to make arrangements concerning storage and on-carriage of the cargo to be discharged, and that the cargo owners were advised to insure the cargo pending on-carriage, if necessary. Next, in their telex of 8 February, the appellants reaffirmed their telex of 3 February and stated that the respondents were to take delivery of the cargo when discharged and that they would inform the respondents when and where the cargo was to be discharged so as to enable them to take delivery. The appellants chose Porbander as the port of discharge. The ship proceeded to Porbander and discharged the cargoes there and stored them at the port godowns. Following that, in their telex dated 13 February to their agents in Khorramshahr, the appellants again stated that it was up to the cargo owners or consignees to make arrangements for their cargoes to be on-carried to their destination on their own account; that the cargo owners were to be responsible for freight, storage, expenses and handling charges; that if they so desired, they should ask the appellants` agents to act on their behalf, and that they must arrange for necessary insurance whilst in storage and in transit from the loading port to the destination. It is abundantly clear that the appellants had selected Porbander as the final port of discharge and upon discharge of the goods there, had treated the contract of carriage as terminated. They had no intention of effecting a transhipment of the goods for on-carriage to Khorramshahr. In our judgment, the appellants in the circumstances had no right to tranship the goods onto the Kota Agung for on-carriage to Khorramshahr.
The goods were stored in the godown for over two months, and the appellants did not communicate with the respondents before they decided to load the goods onto the Kota Agung. It was possible for the appellants to communicate with the respondents and seek their instructions, and indeed there was ample opportunity for the appellants to verify the respondents` wishes in the two months before the arrival of the Kota Agung at Porbander in May 1979. The appellants never sought the respondents` instructions in advance of the goods being loaded on board the Kota Agung and informed the respondents only after the event that the goods had been loaded. The appellants` decision to load the respondents` goods onto the Kota Agung was an unilateral act carried out without the consent of the respondents. It is true that the appellants did telex the respondents on 1 March 1979 asking them if they wished to make their own arrangements for onward forwarding the goods to Khorramshahr or if they wished the appellants` agents to arrange this on their behalf. It is also true that the respondents never responded to this telex. But this silence on the part of the respondents did not amount to an indication of their consent to the transhipment decided by the appellants two months later. It was at all times `reasonably possible` during this period for the appellants to communicate with the respondents `with reasonable expectation of an answer`. They failed to do so.
It was submitted by Mr Thomas for the appellants that, assuming that the contract of carriage was terminated, the appellants by remaining in possession of the goods became involuntary bailees of the goods and their duty was to take such measures to preserve the goods as a man of ordinary prudence would take for the preservation of his own property: 
 China-Pacific SA v Food Corporation of India 
 .2 We accept this proposition. But we do not accept that the appellants in this case were entitled, in fulfilment of their duty as bailees, to load the goods onto the Kota Agung for on-carriage to Khorramshahr without first obtaining the consent or permission from the respondents, though the respondents were apprised of the facts and did not give any instruction for over two months. The case of 
 China- Pacific SA 
 2 does not support the contention made on behalf of the appellants that they were entitled to do so. In that case, the salvors salved a quantity of wheat from a vessel stranded on a reef in the South China Sea and brought the wheat to Manila where it was stored at the salvors` expenses. The salvors informed the cargo owners of the salvage work and asked them to make arrangement to take delivery of the cargo, but there was no response from the cargo owners. Subsequently, the shipowner abandoned the voyage and notified the cargo owners accordingly. The cargo owners refused to pay for storage charges for the period prior to the abandonment of the voyage on the ground that the contract of affreightment was still afoot and the immediate right to possession vested in the shipowners and it was the shipowners who would be liable to the salvors for the expenses incurred during the period. The House of Lords held that the salvage agreement was signed by the master of the ship as agent for the cargo owners and that when the goods were salved and taken into possession by the salvors, the direct relationship of bailor and bailee was created between the cargo owners and the salvors and all the mutual rights and duties attaching to that relationship at common law applied. So long as that relationship continued, the salvors as the bailee owed a duty of care to the cargo owners to take such measures to preserve the salved wheat from deterioration as a man of prudence would take for the preservation of his own property. Arising from this relationship, there was a correlative right of the salvors to reimbursement of expenses incurred by them in taking measures to preserve the property: see the speech of Lord Diplock at pp 960-961. Accordingly, the salvors were held entitled to reimbursement of the expenses reasonably incurred by them in fulfilment of the duty owed to the cargo owners. But the case is not an authority for the proposition contended on behalf of the appellants that a bailee in fulfilling his duty to the bailor may remove the goods, as in this case, without the necessity of communicating with and seeking the direction of the bailor where the bailor has been fully apprised of the facts.
Mr Thomas also submitted that the duty of the appellants as bailees of the goods includes a power to remove the goods to a `better place` and he relied on 
 Cargo ex Argos 
 ,3 
 Great Northern Railway Co v Swaffield 
 4 and 
 Pedrick v Morning Star Motors 
 .5 The cases relied upon do not really support his argument. 
 Cargo ex Argos 
 3 was an appeal to the Privy Council from the High Court of Admiralty. There, petroleum was shipped on board the Argos from London for Havre and on the ship`s arrival at Havre, the authorities required the master to take her away because of the petroleum on board. The ship then sailed to the neighbouring ports but was not allowed to stay. The ship then returned to Havre, but no bill of lading was presented and no application was made for taking delivery of the petroleum. The ship subsequently returned to London bringing the petroleum back. It was held that the shipowner was entitled to the freight, back freight and expenses. Sir Montague E Smith delivering the judgment said, at p 165: 
 
... It is well established that, if the ship has waited a reasonable time to deliver goods from her side, the master may land and warehouse them at the charge of the merchant; and it cannot be doubted that it would be his duty to do so rather than to throw them overboard. In a case like the present, where the goods could neither be landed nor remain where they were, it seems to be a legitimate extension of the implied agency of the master to hold that, in the absence of all advices, he had authority to carry or send them on to such other place as in his judgment, prudently exercised, appeared to be most convenient for their owner; and if so, it will follow from established principles that the expenses properly incurred may be charged to him.
 
 
 
In the 
 Great Northern Railway Co 
 case,4 the facts were entirely different. There, the defendant sent a horse through the plaintiff railway and failed to take delivery at the destination and the plaintiff placed the horse in a livery stable. It was held that the plaintiff acted reasonably and was entitled to be reimbursed all the livery charges which had been paid. In 
 Pedrick v Morning Star Motors 
 ,5 the plaintiff bought a car from the defendant and subsequently sent it to the latter for repairs. After the repairs, the plaintiff refused to take the car complaining that the repairs were unsatisfactory. The defendant, after notice to the plaintiff, placed the car at the public car park where it was subsequently stolen. It was held by the Court of Appeal that the defendant was not under any obligation to keep the car which belonged to the plaintiff and that the plaintiff was in breach of contract in failing to collect it when he was given the opportunity and was urged to collect it, and accordingly the risk of the car was and remained with him. In the course of his judgment, Megaw LJ said: 
 
... It is not a part of a contract, when somebody hands over a chattel to somebody else in order to do work on it, that the person to whom it has been handed over shall be obliged, by virtue of his contract, to keep that chattel - whether it be a white elephant, a motor car, or anything else - indefinitely, for the convenience of the owner and to his own inconvenience and disadvantage.
 
 
 
The factual situation in the instant case is entirely different from those in the three cases. The goods were discharged at Porbander and stored at the port godown. The contract of carriage was terminated. The appellants as bailees were well entitled to be reimbursed by the respondents as bailors for all the storage charges and other expenses incurred. The goods remained in the godown for well over two months, and during this period neither party communicated with each other. There was no evidence or suggestion that the godown at Porbander was not a safe or suitable place for storing the goods; so no question of removing the goods to a safer or more suitable place or `a better place` arose. The appellants were not removing the goods and placing them in `a better place`; they were loading them on board the Kota Agung for transhipment to Khorramshahr in purported performance of the contract which had been terminated.
The appellants did not have contractually the right of transhipment. The loading of the goods on board the Kota Agung was carried out without the respondents` permission or consent and that was for the purpose of on-carriage to Khorramshahr. That they were not entitled to do. In so doing, the appellants went beyond the fulfilment of their duty as bailees and dealt with the goods in a manner inconsistent with the respondents` right. In our opinion, in loading the goods on board the Kota Agung without the permission or consent of the respondents, the appellants committed conversion of the goods. Even if that was not conversion, the appellants clearly committed conversion subsequently in refusing to unload the goods from Kota Agung upon request by the respondents. As the learned judge said, by transhipping the goods against or contrary to the instructions of the respondents, the appellants asserted a right which was inconsistent with the respondents` right. The learned judge further found, and this was not challenged, that the appellants in transhipping the goods intended to charge freight and to claim a lien on the goods for freight and that in so doing, the appellants intended to assert dominion over the goods. In our judgment, the transhipment of the goods by the appellants constituted conversion.
The learned judge also found that the appellants had committed trespass to the goods. In our opinion, the evidence adduced was more than sufficient to support such a finding. Trespass to goods is a wrongful physical interference with them. Removing someone`s goods against his wishes is a trespass. Thus, in removing the respondents` goods from the godown at Porbander and loading them onto the Kota Agung and thereafter retaining them on board against the demand by the respondents, the appellants committed trespass to the goods.
The appellants committed conversion of and trespass to the goods, and the goods were lost whilst they were in their unlawful possession. The appellants were in the position of insurers of the goods and in the events that happened were liable for the loss, whether or not they were negligent: 
 Shaw & Co v Symmons & 
 
 Sons 
 .6 In that case, the plaintiffs entrusted books to the defendants, a bookbinder, to be bound and to be redelivered when bound to the plaintiffs. The plaintiffs subsequently requested the defendants to redeliver the books which had been bound but the defendants failed to do so within a reasonable time. The books were subsequently destroyed by fire in the defendants` premises, and the defendants were held liable for the loss. Avory J having referred to 
 Davis v 
 
 Garrett 
 7 at p 724 and other cases, said at p 801: 
 
... To quote the words of Tindal CJ in 
 Davis v Garrett
 (1830) 6 Bing 716 at p 724, `as a loss has actually happened whilst his wrongful act was in operation and force`, they cannot set up as an answer to the action the bare possibility of a loss if their wrongful act had never been done.
 
 
 
This decision was followed in 
 Mitchell v Ealing London Borough Council 
 8 where a gratuitous bailee was held liable for the loss of the goods as insurer after it had failed to return the goods to the bailor as previously arranged. O`Connor J said, at p 9: 
 
Applying the law laid down in 
 Shaw & Co v Symmons & Sons
 
[1917] 1 KB 799
 to the facts of the present case (sympathetic as I am with the defendants) it seems to me that the failure of the defendants to send their representative to the agreed place for the delivery of the goods was a negligent failure on their part, and from that moment they became insurers of the goods. As I have said in the earlier part of this judgment the plaintiff`s claim has no merits to support it, but the law, in my judgment, is clear. It was a mistake on the part of the defendants, and, as I have said, I have great sympathy with them that they were unable to rectify it. But the arrangement made on 17 December fits precisely into the pattern of the law as I recognize it to be well established, and the failure of the defendants to keep the appointment was a failure which makes them responsible thereafter for the loss of the goods.
 
 
 
We now turn to the alternative claim by the respondents against the appellants as bailees of the goods for breach of duty and/or negligence. It was not in dispute that the goods were damaged by fire and the goods at the material time were in the possession and control of the appellants, and the burden is on them to prove that the fire was not occasioned by their negligence. The learned judge found that they had not proved the probable cause of the fire and had not discharged the burden. However, he found that the opening of the hatches during the lunch break of three hours substantially increased the risks of fire occurring to the goods and that the master was negligent or in breach of duty in not closing the hatches during the lunch break. On the evidence, he was justified in making these findings. In particular, the master testified in evidence that he was aware of the highly sensitive and combustible nature of the cargo; that he was aware of the fire hazards; that he was aware of the volatile state of affairs in Khorramshahr, but that he had decided on the `ventilation` of the holds as important and was content to leave the hatches open for such a long period of time despite the risk of damage this would pose to the cargo.
We now turn to the last issue, and that is whether s 271 of the Merchant Shipping Act (Cap 179) applies to relieve the appellants from liability for the loss of the goods. The section provides: 
 
The owner of a British ship ... shall not be liable to make good to any extent whatever any loss or damage happening without his actual fault or privity in the following cases:
 
 
 
 
(a) where any goods, merchandise or other thing whatsoever taken in or put on board his ship are lost or damaged by reason of fire on board the ship; ...
  
 
 
(Under s 3 of the Merchant Shipping Act `British ship` is construed as `Singapore ship`.)
 
 
 
The learned judge held that this section had no application in this case where goods were carried on board the ship without the consent of the owner of the goods. It was submitted by Mr Thomas on behalf of the appellants that since the learned judge had found that the loss of the goods by fire on board the Kota Agung happened without actual fault or privity of the appellants, they were exempted from liability by reason of the statutory provision and he challenged the conclusion of the learned judge that the provision was not applicable. He contended that the provision was based on public policy and the expedient protection of shipowners. We find it unnecessary to consider whether the learned judge`s conclusion is correct. Even if what was contended by Mr Thomas is correct, the statutory provision is of no assistance to the appellants. The torts of conversion of and trespass to the goods had been committed by the appellants before the fire took place, and the appellants` liability to the respondents had already arisen, and, as the learned judge held, they were in the position of insurers and were liable for any loss howsoever incurred.
In the result, the appeal is dismissed with costs. In our opinion, this appeal merits the issue of a certificate of two solicitors pursuant to O 59 r 19. We accordingly so order. There will be the usual consequential order that the deposit paid into court as security be paid to the respondents or their solicitors.
Outcome:

title: Ong Ah Yeo Yenna v Public Prosecutor [1993] SGHC 41
content:
Ong Ah Yeo Yenna v Public Prosecutor
[1993] SGHC 41
 
 
Case Number
 
:
 
Cr Rev 10/1992
 
 
 
Decision Date
 
:
 
24 February 1993
 
 
 
Tribunal/Court
 
:
 
High Court
 
 
 
Coram
 
:
 
 
Yong Pung How CJ
 
 
 
 
Counsel Name(s)
 
:
 
 R Palakrishnan (Palakrishnan & Partners) for the petitioner; Hamidul Haq and Rosalind Chong (State Counsel) for the respondent 
 
 
 
Parties
 
:
 
 Ong Ah Yeo Yenna — Public Prosecutor 
 
 
 
Criminal Law
  – 
Abetment
  – 
Intentionally aiding commission of offence
  – 
Liability of abettor
  – 
Whether abettor may be convicted if principal has not been found guilty of offence abetted
  – 
Whether statement of facts tendered by prosecution supported charge
  – 
ss 107 & 108 Penal Code (Cap 224)
 
 
Criminal Procedure and Sentencing
  – 
Particulars
  – 
Charge
  – 
Improper charge
  – 
Abetment of commission of criminal breach of trust
  – 
Failure to state that moneys misappropriated by principal was property which principal was entrusted with dominion over
  – 
Effect thereof
  – 
s 405 Penal Code (Cap 224)
 
 
Cur Adv Vult
 
This is a petition for criminal revision in which the petitioner seeks to have set aside her conviction of 22 May 1992 on the following charge, on the basis that her plea of guilt to this charge ought not to have been accepted by the district court: 
 
You, Yenna Ong Ah Yeo, are charged that you between 20 and 22 June 1990, in Singapore, abetted one Lim Teck Cheng, a director of Wyno Marine Pte Ltd (`Wyno`) who in such capacity being entrusted with dominion over property, namely, moneys belonging to Wyno, to commit criminal breach of trust as an agent, in that you intentionally aided the said Lim Teck Cheng to dishonestly misappropriate the sum of $282,000 when you arranged for Wyno to pay to one Lee & Kong Engineering Works the said sum pursuant to two invoices Nos 1267/90 and 1268/90 both dated 20 June 1990 and have thereby committed an offence punishable under s 409 read with s 109 of the Penal Code (Cap 224).
 
 
 
On her plea of guilt and subsequent conviction, she was sentenced to six months` imprisonment. The main grounds she relies upon in asking for revision of those proceedings are as follows. First, the principal accused, Lim Teck Cheng, has claimed trial to the charge against him of committing the offence of criminal breach of trust which the petitioner has been convicted of abetting. Secondly, she has been advised that the statement of facts tendered by the prosecution in support of the charge set out above did not in fact support that charge.
Counsel`s first main submission was that where a principal accused has not been found guilty of an offence, no person may be convicted of intentionally aiding such an offence. Section 108 of the Penal Code (Cap 224) provides that: 
 
A person abets an offence who abets either the commission of an offence, or the commission of an act which would be an offence, if committed by a person capable by law of committing an offence with the same intention or knowledge as that of the abettor.
 
 
 
Explanation 2 of this section is as follows: 
 
To constitute the offence of abetment, it is not necessary that the act abetted should be committed, or that the effect requisite to constitute the offence should be caused.
 
 
 
Explanation 2 may not immediately appear to be within the plain meaning of s 108, but illustration (a) of this explanation is: 
 
A instigates B to murder C. B refuses to do so. A is guilty of abetting B to commit murder.
 
 
 
The express words of explanation 2 and illustration (a) are sufficient to show that, for an abettor to be convicted, the principal accused need not always be proved to have committed the offence (or the actus reus of the offence) for which he is charged.
Counsel contended that nevertheless, where the alleged abetment takes the specific form of intentional aid, rather than instigation or conspiracy, the principal must be found guilty of the offence aided before the abettor may be convicted, because `a person cannot aid another in doing something which that other has not done` (per Avory J in 
 Morris v Tolman 
 1).
In 
 Faguna Kanta Nath v State of Assam 
 ,2 the court said at p 674: 
 
In the case of abetment by aid a person can be said to abet by aiding only when by the commission of an act he intends to facilitate the commission of the offence and does facilitate the commission thereof. Therefore where a person is charged with abetment by aid of an offence under s 161 and the person charged with the offence is acquitted on the ground that he had not committed the offence no question of intentionally aiding by any act or omission the commission of that offence arises. Therefore whether the acquittal is right or wrong the conviction of the abettor also cannot be allowed to stand in the circumstances.
 
 
 
In 
 Jamuna Singh v State of Bihar 
 ,3 the court said: 
 
It is not necessary for the offence of abetment that the act abetted must be committed. It is only in the case of a person abetting an offence by intentionally aiding another to commit that offence that the charge of abetment against him would be expected to fail when the person alleged to have committed the offence is acquitted of that offence.
 
 
 
I have considered these and other authorities cited to me and I am persuaded that they are consistent with counsel`s proposition. In the normal case the charge against an abettor should state the act he is alleged to have abetted. This is as true of charges of abetment by intentional aid as it is of charges of abetment by instigation or conspiracy. This act therefore forms part of the prosecution`s case against the alleged abettor. There is in the meaning of `instigation` and `conspiracy` no inherent assumption that either the instigation or the conspiracy came to fruition, and so while the act instigated or conspired towards by the abettor can and must be identified, the fact that its actual commission might not be proved is unobjectionable. Conversely, the word `aid` does imply that the act aided was committed, so it follows that the prosecution must prove the commission of the act which an abettor is alleged to have aided intentionally.
Indeed the prosecution must prove more than this. Intentionally aiding the commission of an act is not the same as intentionally aiding the commission of an offence. Explanation 2 of s 107 of the Penal Code reads: 
 
Whoever, either prior to or at the time of the commission of an act, does anything in order to facilitate the commission of that act, and thereby facilitates the commission thereof, is said to aid the doing of that act.
 
 
 
This, read with s 108, indicates that a person may abet an offence who aids in the commission of an act which might only be a constituent part of the whole actus reus of the offence. If he may only be said to have aided where the aid has given results, then it follows that he may only be said to have intentionally aided that offence if the whole actus reus of the offence itself is proved to have been committed. If it has not and only the act which forms a part of the actus reus of the offence has been proved to have been committed, his intentional aiding of that act may only support his liability for intentionally aiding an attempted commission of the offence (assuming the evidence amounts to such attempt).
However, I would depart from many of the Indian cases in the following respect. The fact that the act intentionally aided must have been committed does not mean that the principal should of necessity have been convicted prior to the alleged abettor in order that the latter may be found liable for aiding him. The sequence in which the principal and the intentional aider are tried is frequently a matter of chance; and indeed, on occasion it may not be possible to try the principal at any time at all, for example, where he dies before trial or where he cannot be found. It is quite unacceptable that in these cases the intentional aider should also be immune from liability.
Moreover the conviction of the abettor turns on the evidence against him, which may be different from that admitted against the principal. I turn gratefully to the judgment of West J in 
 R v Maruti Dada 
 4 for the full expression of this conception: 
 
The offence of abetment under the Penal Code is a substantive offence ... By the Indian as well as the English procedure, an abettor may be convicted before the principal is arrested. The principal may then be tried and acquitted, but in this case the abettor has not suffered any wrong. A rational doubt may exist as to the identity or guilt of the principal through the legal exclusion as to him of particular portions of the evidence, and yet there may be no possible doubt as to the guilt of the abettor, in whose case the rules of exclusion do not happen to operate. It would be a perversion of the rules of evidence if because the operation of a rule is to exclude evidence against a principal, A, it should operate to the acquittal of an abettor, B, who may have fully confessed ... and may, without doubt, be guilty. The mere circumstance that B is tried along with A, instead of at a different trial, cannot alter the real force of the case against him.
 
 
 
Again, in 
 R v Humphreys and Turner 
 5 there is an instructive passage in the judgment of Chapman J: 
 
It may seem anomalous ... that even if a principal offender is acquitted, a conviction of aiding and abetting him may still be valid, but the logic of the situation is wrapped up in the rules of evidence. In a case where two people are charged a jury is always directed to consider each case separately. This is because the evidence as against one accused or another may be quite different in validity (ie admissibility) or strength. ... It would be anomalous if a person who admitted to a substantial part in the perpetration of a misdemeanour as aider and abettor could not be convicted on his own admission merely because the person alleged to have been aided and abetted was not or could not be convicted.
 
 
 
In my view, the court which tries an abettor on a charge of intentionally aiding an offence must direct its mind towards making a finding as to whether or not the whole actus reus of the offence he is alleged to have aided was in fact committed; and the court may, indeed must, do so in all cases, including those where the principal has not been convicted of that offence by the time the alleged intentional aider is tried.
In short, although illustration (a) of explanation 2 of s 108 indicates that an abettor`s liability may extend beyond situations in which the principal is entitled to be acquitted on the basis of a defence personal to himself to situations where the actus reus of the offence has not been committed, this extension cannot apply where the abetment takes the form of intentional aid rather than instigation or conspiracy.
No doubt the danger of inconsistent verdicts becomes live as a result of this interpretation since, for example, the court which tries the principal may acquit him whereas the intentional aider might have been convicted earlier, implying possibly incompatible findings made by two courts as to the principal`s liability. In the first place, the potential discrepancy between such findings does not mean this procedure is logically flawed, as explained in the passages quoted from 
 R v Maruti Dada 
 4 and 
 R v Humphreys and Turner 
 .5 Further, many other factors and interests are operative. In my view, it would be unworkable and prejudicial to the public interest to insist unwaveringly upon the ideal that the principal and the intentional aider should always be tried in some particular order even though, where they are not tried in that order, the spectre of inconsistent verdicts will be unavoidable.
Applying these principles to the present case, the court before which the petitioner pleaded guilty had to have been satisfied on the material before it, namely, the prosecution`s statement of facts tendered in support of the charge against the petitioner, that Lim Teck Cheng had committed the actus reus of the offence the petitioner was alleged to have abetted. The fact that Lim Teck Cheng had chosen to claim trial should not have affected that finding. Therefore all that was required of the prosecution was that the statement of facts should disclose, inter alia, the actus reus of the offence she was alleged to have abetted. Counsel`s second main submission questioned whether the statement of facts tendered in this case did in fact support the charge against the petitioner. I therefore turn to examine this issue, for which I will set out the relevant facts.
The prosecution had to show first that Lim Teck Cheng, being entrusted as a director of Wyno with dominion over moneys belonging to it, had misappropriated the sum of $282,000 and thereby committed the actus reus of the offence of criminal breach of trust as an agent of that company. The prosecution also had to show that the petitioner aided Lim Teck Cheng in performing the misappropriation by arranging for that company to pay to one Lee & Kong Engineering Works the said sum pursuant to the two invoices described in the charge. Further, the prosecution had to show that the petitioner did so intentionally - that is, with the intention that Lim Teck Cheng should misappropriate the moneys. The statement of facts tendered by the prosecution disclosed the following facts.
From 26 June 1989 the petitioner worked as an accountant in a company called Hong Lam Marine Pte Ltd (`Hong Lam`). On 13 September 1989 she was appointed a director of that company, her fellow director being Lim Teck Cheng. On 13 February 1990 the petitioner was also appointed a director of Wyno, a recently formed company whose other directors were Lim Teck Cheng and one Koh Chye Heng.
In June 1990 Lim Teck Cheng told the petitioner and Koh Chye Heng that he had approached International Factors Marine (S) Pte Ltd (`IFM`) for a loan of $4.2m for the construction of a vessel, and that as a condition of the loan, Hong Lam had to show IFM that expenses of $500,000 had already been incurred by it in the construction of the vessel. Lim Teck Cheng said that Hong Lam could not fulfil this condition and after some discussion, it was agreed that Wyno should ask its subcontractors to issue false invoices, on which Wyno should pay them, after which they would simply return the money to Lim Teck Cheng.
In pursuance of this scheme, Lim Teck Cheng later specifically instructed the petitioner to obtain false invoices from Lee & Kong Engineering Works. On or around 20 June 1990 the petitioner signed two purchase orders, Nos WM102-3001 and WM102-3002, on behalf of Koh Chye Heng, from Wyno to Lee & Kong Engineering Works. Lee & Kong Engineering Works then issued their invoices, Nos 1267/90 for $240,000 and 1268/90 for $42,000 in respect of these purchase orders. On or around 22 June 1990 the petitioner raised a payment voucher No 067/06/90 for $282,000 in respect of the two invoices. Lim Teck Cheng, who controlled the moneys belonging to Wyno, issued a cheque for that sum. This was given to Lee & Kong Engineering Works, who promptly issued a cheque returning the sum to the petitioner, who in turn handed it back to Lim Teck Cheng. This cheque was encashed by Lim Teck Cheng and the moneys deposited in Hong Lam`s bank account.
On or around 27 June 1990 Lim Teck Cheng handed the petitioner a deposit slip dated that day for an amount of $298,500, informing her that this sum comprised the $282,000 returned by Lee & Kong Engineering Works and a $16,500 loan from `Winoso Trading`. He instructed the petitioner to record the total amount in the accounts of Hong Lam as a loan from himself and she did so. Before the petitioner left Hong Lam in 1991, she told Lim Teck Cheng that he should reverse the $282,000 that was recorded in Wyno`s accounts as construction costs of the vessel and in Hong Lam`s accounts as a loan. Up to the date the petitioner pleaded guilty, this had not been done.
This is the sum of the relevant facts in the prosecution`s statement of facts. The loss in the transaction was suffered by Wyno: $282,000 which originally belonged to Wyno became totally disengaged from that company, being transformed instead into a debt owed to Lim Teck Cheng by Hong Lam. The charge against the petitioner alleges that her abetment of Lim Teck Cheng`s criminal breach of trust took the form of arranging for Wyno to pay the $282,000 to Lee & Kong Engineering Works pursuant to the invoices. Yet it is not stated anywhere in the statement of facts that at the time the petitioner arranged for the said payment she knew that she would be asked to record the money returned from Lee & Kong Engineering Works as a loan to Hong Lam rather than as an asset belonging to Wyno. If anything, the statement of facts indicated that the petitioner would have thought that the money would be returned to Wyno, which would then have been no worse off than before the payment out was made. Her intention at the time she did the acts for which she was charged, namely, arranging for Wyno to pay the money to Lee & Kong Engineering Works pursuant to the two invoices dated 20 June 1990, was simply not addressed at all in the statement of facts.
This being the case, even if it is assumed in favour of the prosecution that the statement of facts did disclose the commission of the act/s constituting the offence of criminal breach of trust as an agent alleged against Lim Teck Cheng, the petitioner has still not been proven to have intentionally aided the commission of such act/s. She has not been shown to have arranged for the payment to Lee & Kong Engineering Works with the intention that Lim Teck Cheng should misappropriate the moneys.
This alone is sufficient for my decision. The statement of facts hinted at an overall scheme devised to extract money wrongfully from IFM; alternately, the petitioner`s obedience to Lim Teck Cheng`s instructions to record the deposit in Hong Lam`s bank account as a loan might have been questionable. However, the statement of facts, as it stood, did not permit of more than mere conjecture as to these possibilities, nor did it disclose enough for a substitute charge to be sensibly drafted. This court cannot and will not, in the face of the limited material before it, take upon itself the duty of the prosecution either in deciding what charge might have been appropriate, or in plugging by surmise the deficiencies in the facts laid before it. For the same reasons, s 111 of the Penal Code, on the facts before the court, will not assist the prosecution in the absence of any factual or legal material on which this court may conclude that the alleged criminal breach of trust was a probable consequence of the aid rendered by the petitioner. From the facts which were disclosed, the activities described seem undeniably highly suspect. However, to say any more would be an unjustified exercise in speculation which cannot make up for an improperly drafted charge or statement of facts.
I would make one other observation. The charge itself was strictly improper. The relevant portions of s 405 of the Penal Code are as follows: 
 
Whoever, being in any manner entrusted with ... any dominion over property, dishonestly misappropriates ... that property ... commits `criminal breach of trust`. (Emphasis added.)
 
 
 
The charge in the present case alleged only that the petitioner `intentionally aided the said Lim Teck Cheng to dishonestly misappropriate the sum of $282,000`. There was no mention of the $282,000 being the property which Lim Teck Cheng was entrusted with dominion over, though this was in fact the case and there was ample and undisputed evidence as to this. That is, though Lim Teck Cheng was described in the charge as a director of Wyno who in such capacity was entrusted with dominion over property, namely, moneys belonging to Wyno, it was not also alleged in the charge that the salient $282,000 misappropriated were moneys belonging to Wyno. On the facts, this was a minor point and were it the sole objection to the proceedings against the petitioner would no doubt have merited little concern. As it is, the cumulative deficiencies in the prosecution case are not to be lightly regarded.
In all the circumstances of this case, I am of the view that the proper course for me in the interests of justice would be to grant the petition and set aside the petitioner`s conviction. I do so accordingly. The costs of prosecution paid by the petitioner must be refunded to her.
Outcome:
